questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of acute shortness of breath and chest pain. The chest pain is retrosternal in nature and does not radiate. She feels nauseated but has not vomited. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. Current medications include insulin, aspirin, metoprolol, and hydrochlorothiazide. She is pale and diaphoretic. Her temperature is 37.0째C (98째F), pulse is 136/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention and absence of a radial pulse during inspiration. Crackles are heard at the lung bases bilaterally. Cardiac examination shows distant heart sounds. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
8.3 g/dL


Serum



Glucose
313 mg/dL


Urea nitrogen
130 mg/dL


Creatinine
6.0 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Severe pericardial effusion and subsequent cardiac tamponade are life-threatening conditions that require immediate decompression with pericardiocentesis. Pericardiocentesis is indicated for hemodynamic stabilization and symptom relief before treatment of the underlying condition (e.g., with hemodialysis) can be started. This patient with diabetes has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD), likely as a result of inadequately managed hyperglycemia. CKD leads to elevation of both serum creatinine and BUN, which can result in chronic pericardial effusion due to uremia. The patient's anemia (due to decreased EPO levels) and bilateral crackles indicating pulmonary edema (due to fluid retention) also likely result from CKD.

In hemodynamically stable patients with pericardial effusion, the underlying cause should be treated first. If an effusion is due to underlying malignancy, a pericardial window is performed to continuously drain the fluid.
Image Description:

Echocardiography transthoracic (apical view; A: without needle; B and C: with needle)

Anechoic pericardial effusion (PE) was identified. Needle position (arrows) was continuously monitored while the pericardial space was entered to drain the effusion.

Arrowheads: myocardium

B) INCORRECT:

Hemodialysis is commonly performed in patients with end-stage renal disease. This patient has chronic kidney disease that has resulted in uremia and pericardial effusion. The patient should undergo hemodialysis, but she is hemodynamically unstable and presents with signs of cardiac tamponade, which makes a different procedure more appropriate at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

IV fluid infusion is likely indicated in this patient since she is hemodynamically unstable. However, she has cardiac tamponade; fluid resuscitation can only provide temporary relief and should not delay the treatment of the cardiac tamponade. Moreover, the patient has chronic kidney disease and shows signs of end-stage renal disease such as uremia, which means that fluids should only be administered with extreme caution.

D) INCORRECT:

While this patient likely has fluid overload due to reduced renal function, she is hemodynamically unstable. Administration of furosemide will further decrease her blood pressure and is therefore contraindicated. Moreover, diuretics are usually insufficient to remove excess fluids in patients with end-stage renal disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient is hemodynamically unstable and presents with low blood pressure, norepinephrine is not indicated in this case. She most likely has cardiac tamponade, which necessitates a different procedure first. Additionally, it is not clear if norepinephrine infusion is beneficial in patients with cardiac tamponade.

F) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs (e.g., aspirin) are used in the treatment of viral pericarditis. While patients with viral pericarditis can develop pericardial effusion and in some cases even cardiac tamponade, they usually present with additional symptoms such as fever, leukocytosis, and a history of respiratory and/or gastrointestinal symptoms. This patient has none of these findings, making viral pericarditis an unlikely diagnosis. Furthermore, she is hemodynamically unstable, which requires a more urgent intervention.
questions.hint: This hemodynamically unstable patient presents with Beck triad (hypotension, distant heart sounds, and jugular venous distention), pulsus paradoxus (absent pulse during inspiration), and chest pain, all of which indicate cardiac tamponade.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sharp chest pain for 3 days. The pain is retrosternal, 8 out of 10 in intensity, increases with respiration, and decreases while sitting upright and leaning forward. He has nausea and myalgia. He has not had fever or a cough. He has asthma and was treated for bronchitis 6 months ago with azithromycin. His mother has hypertension. He uses an over-the-counter inhaler. His temperature is 37.3째C (99.1째F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Breath sounds are normal. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched grating sound between S1 and S2. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Urea nitrogen
16 mg/dl


Glucose
93 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.7 mg/dL


Troponin I
0.23 ng/mL


An ECG shows diffuse ST elevations in all leads. The patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture is a life-threatening complication of acute myocardial infarction (MI) that leads to mitral regurgitation with subsequent hypotension and pulmonary edema. Although this patient presents with chest pain, symptoms of acute MI do not usually last for three consecutive days and present with ST elevations in anatomically contiguous leads on ECG.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary infarction is most commonly caused by pulmonary embolism (PE), which can also present with chest pain and nonspecific ST elevation. However, other common features of PE would be expected, including dyspnea, tachypnea, cough, hypotension, or signs of right ventricular pressure overload on ECG (e.g., right axis deviation). The absence of these symptoms in this case, as well as the presence of a friction rub on auscultation, make pulmonary embolism and therefore pulmonary infarction unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Mediastinitis may occur as a result of esophageal disorders (e.g., Boerhaave syndrome). Patients with Boerhaave syndrome often present with a history of explosive vomiting and symptoms such as retrosternal pain and mediastinal emphysema (Mackler triad). The retrosternal pain seen in this patient makes Boerhaave syndrome an important differential diagnosis. However, in this case, the patient's history, auscultatory and ECG findings are suggestive of a different disease.

D) CORRECT:

Pericarditis is a common cause of cardiac tamponade; it may occur in cases in which the pericardium becomes scarred and less elastic, while increased amounts of inflammatory fluids are secreted into the pericardial space. Cardiac tamponade can lead to hemodynamic compromise; therefore, treatment with pericardiocentesis is indicated.

Another complication of acute pericarditis is chronic, constrictive pericarditis, which may develop after several years.

E) INCORRECT:

A ventricular aneurysm is a late (> 3 weeks) complication of myocardial infarction (MI) that presents with persistent ST elevations and T wave inversions on ECG and can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and thromboembolisms. Although this patient presents with chest pain, symptoms of acute MI do not usually last for three consecutive days and present with more specific findings on ECG. Considering the timing and that MI is unlikely, ventricular aneurysm can be ruled out.
questions.hint: The patient's 3-day history of chest pain that increases with respiration and decreases while sitting up, in conjunction with a friction rub on cardiac auscultation, nausea, and myalgia, is suggestive of acute pericarditis. The ECG finding of ST elevations in all leads with a mild increase in troponin I further support the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest. On arrival, he has rapid, shallow breathing and appears anxious. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min and shallow, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 80 mm Hg. Examination shows no active external bleeding. There is a 2.5-cm single stab wound to the left chest at the 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Cardiovascular examination shows muffled heart sounds and jugular venous distention. Breath sounds are normal. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Tracheal deviation toward the right side
A drop in systolic blood pressure of 14 mm Hg during inspiration
Herniation of the stomach into the chest
Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tracheal deviation toward the contralateral side of a lesion can occur with a tension pneumothorax or a massive hemothorax. Although both of these conditions can be caused by penetrating chest trauma and result in tachycardia, hypotension, and jugular venous distention, this patient does not have reduced breath sounds, which is a characteristic auscultatory finding in both of these conditions.

B) CORRECT:

In cardiac tamponade, outward expansion of the ventricles is limited because of fluid in the pericardial space. During inspiration, increased venous return leads to increased right ventricular volume. As outward expansion is limited, the right ventricle expands via the interventricular septum, which bulges into the left ventricle. This effect leads to further reduction in left ventricular filling during inspiration, resulting in decreased stroke volume and a subsequent drop in blood pressure. A drop in systolic blood pressure > 10 mm Hg during inspiration is known as pulsus paradoxus, a sign characteristically seen in moderate and severe cardiac tamponade but also in some cases of severe asthma, tension pneumothorax, and constrictive pericarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

Herniation of the stomach into the chest indicates diaphragmatic injury. This condition may also result after a penetrating chest trauma. Although shallow breathing is a feature consistent with diaphragmatic injury, this patient is lacking other key findings of this condition, such as chest or abdominal pain, reduced breath sounds, and bowel sounds in the chest on auscultation. In addition, muffled heart sounds would not be expected in this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous emphysema or crepitus suggests either bronchial rupture, esophageal rupture, or pneumothorax, which also may be caused by penetrating trauma. None of these conditions cause muffled heart sounds.

E) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing suggests flail chest, which is usually caused by severe blunt thoracic trauma rather than penetrating chest trauma. Although this patient has shallow breathing, which may be a feature of flail chest, the condition is not associated with muffled heart sounds or jugular venous distention, and it is unlikely that a single stab wound would cause several rib fractures.
Image Description:

Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.
questions.hint: Muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and jugular venous distention (also known as Beck triad) following penetrating chest trauma are consistent with cardiac tamponade.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of increasing shortness of breath. He has also had chest pain that is exacerbated by deep inspiration. He has had recurrent episodes of pain in his fingers for the past 2 years. Two years ago, he was treated for a deep vein thrombosis. He has hypertension and anxiety. Current medications include enalapril, St. John's wort, and ibuprofen. His temperature is 37째C (98.6째F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctiva. There is tenderness to palpation of the proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands. Heart sounds are distant. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.9 g/dL


Leukocyte count
4200/mm3



Platelet count
330,000/mm3



Serum



Na+

136 mEq/L


K+

4.3 mEq/L


Antinuclear antibodies
1: 320


Anti-Sm antibodies
positive


Anti-CCP antibodies
negative


An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on this patient's ECG?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pseudo right bundle branch block refers to an ECG finding seen in some inherited arrhythmia syndromes (e.g., Brugada syndrome) and in some patients with left-sided accessory pathways. Both conditions are often found incidentally but may manifest with ventricular tachyarrhythmias, syncope, or sudden cardiac death. Pseudo right bundle branch block is not consistent with pericarditis or pericardial effusion.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 50 mm/s)

Regular sinus rhythm
Heart rate: 83/min
Right axis deviation: R < S in I, R > S in aVF
ST elevation 2 mm and a negative T wave in V1 and V2 (red overlay). The shape of ST elevation seen in V1 is described as coved.
Pseudo-RBBB: The ST changes create a pattern resembling RBBB in V1.

Pseudo-RBBB with ST elevation in V1V3 is characteristic of Brugada pattern. To diagnose Brugada syndrome, the corresponding clinical criteria must also be met, e.g., VF, syncope, or pertinent family history.

B) INCORRECT:

Prolongation of the QT interval can be a seen in hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and inherited long QT syndrome and may be a side effect of various medications. This patient has no symptoms of hypomagnesemia (e.g., tetany, spasm, cramps), his serum potassium is normal, and none of his current medications would have a significant effect on the QT interval. Pericarditis and pericardial effusion does not cause an increased QT interval.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Regular sinus rhythm with a heart rate of approx. 107/min (tachycardia)
- Normal cardiac axis (zoom-box)
- Normal PR interval (approx.160 ms)
- Negative T-wave in III (green circles), T-wave not clearly discernible in V3
- Prolonged (corrected) QT interval with approx. 494 ms

These findings suggest a long QT syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Second-degree AV block is a conduction abnormality that may occur in a variety of diseases (e.g., structural heart disease, electrolyte disorders). While AV blocks can lower cardiac output and consequently cause shortness of breath, most patients are asymptomatic. Less commonly, second-degree AV block manifests with dizziness or syncope (Stokes Adams attacks). Findings in second-degree AV block include irregular heartbeat and bradycardia; there are no radiological findings in isolated AV blocks. Pericarditis with pericardial effusion does not typically cause AV blocks.
Image Description:

ECG strip (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

Regular P waves at a rate of 80/min (green overlay)
There is progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a P wave is not conducted (in this example, the fourth, which is not followed by a QRS complex) and the progression restarts.

D) INCORRECT:

A deep Q wave on ECG can be seen in the intermediate or chronic stages of myocardial infarction (MI). While MI can also manifest with chest pain and shortness of breath, the onset of symptoms is usually acute and the pain is often described as pressure, squeezing, or tightness in the chest. In some patients with MI, a new murmur can be observed on auscultation, but not diminished heart sounds. In MI, an x-ray may show signs of decompensation like pulmonary edema. Pericarditis and pericardial effusion does not cause deep Q waves on ECG.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

Sinus rhythm
Heart rate: 90/min
Left axis deviation (R wave > S wave in lead I, R < S in aVF and II)
ST elevation in V2V4 (example indicated by ST)
Pathological Q waves in V1V4 (example indicated by Q)
T-wave inversion in V1V4 (example indicated by T)
Reduced R wave amplitude in V4V6 (example indicated by R)

These findings are consistent with the intermediate stage of an anterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction.

E) CORRECT:

Electrical alternans is an ECG finding that is highly specific to large pericardial effusions. This finding is characterized by cyclical changes (alterations) in the axis or amplitude of consecutive QRS complexes, which can be attributed to the swinging motion of the beating heart surrounded by pericardial fluid. In addition, ECG in patients with large pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade typically shows sinus tachycardia and low voltage recording.

Management of pericardial effusion depends on the patient's hemodynamic stability: In stable patients, transthoracic echocardiography should be used to confirm the diagnosis. In unstable patients and those in cardiac arrest with suspected tamponade, pericardiocentesis should not be delayed for diagnostic confirmation.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Narrow-complex tachycardia with a ventricular rate of approx. 150/min
- Likely atrial fibrillation (irregular RR intervals, no definitive P waves)
- Normal cardiac axis (R > S in both I and aVF)
- QRS voltage is low, and consecutive R waves alternate in height (electrical alternans, red lines)

The combination of tachycardia, low QRS voltage, and electrical alternans is highly suggestive of a large pericardial effusion.

F) INCORRECT:

The S1Q3T3 pattern is an ECG sign that indicates right-heart strain. Despite its low sensitivity and specificity, S1Q3T3 pattern is classically associated with pulmonary embolism (PE). This patient's history of DVT is a risk factor for PE, which can manifest with shortness of breath, tachycardia, and pleuritic chest pain. However, auscultation would reveal either normal or decreased breath sounds, not distant heart sounds. In PE, chest x-rays are most commonly normal or show nonspecific findings such as atelectasis or pleural effusion. Rare findings that are more specific to PE include Hampton hump and Westermark sign, neither of which are present in this patient's x-ray. Pericarditis and pericardial effusion does not typically cause right-heart strain and an S1Q3T3 pattern.
Image Description:

12 channel ECG with sinus rhythm, negative T-wave in V1-V5, and S1Q3T3 pattern (S wave in lead I, Q wave in lead III and negative T-wave in lead III).

Findings of a negative T-wave in the anterior leads and an S1Q3T3 pattern suggest an acute pulmonary embolism.
questions.hint: Dyspnea, distant heart sounds, tachycardia, pleuritic chest pain, and a chest x-ray showing an enlarged cardiac silhouette with a globular "water bottle-shaped" heart (water bottle sign) make pericarditis with pericardial effusion the most likely diagnosis. In the setting of arthralgia, anemia, leukopenia, positive antinuclear antibodies, positive anti-Sm antibodies, and a history of deep vein thrombosis indicative of antiphospholipid syndrome, this patient's pericardial effusion is most likely due to underlying systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after being involved in a car accident. The patient has sustained injuries to his right arm and leg and his torso. He reports pain in the middle of his chest and shortness of breath. He did not lose consciousness. His temperature is 37째C (98.6째F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows several injuries to the upper extremities and chest. There are jugular venous pulsations 10 cm above the sternal angle. Heart sounds are faint on cardiac examination. The lungs are clear to auscultation. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the chest in this patient could show an enlarged cardiac silhouette, which would point to the presence of an effusion. However, there is a more specific and reliable test to confirm the suspected diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is used to detect aortic dissection in unstable patients. This patient's chest pain and motor vehicle accident should raise concern for aortic dissection, but the muffled heart sounds, ECG changes, and jugular venous distention point to a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Contrast-enhanced CT angiography is used to diagnose aortic dissection in a stable patient. This patient's chest pain and motor vehicle accident should raise concern for aortic dissection, but the muffled heart sounds, ECG changes, and jugular venous distention point to a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Emergency needle thoracostomy is used to treat tension pneumothorax, which is an important diagnosis to rule out in patients with blunt trauma, shortness of breath, and chest pain. However, physical examination typically shows decreased breath sounds in the affected lung and ECG would not show electric alternans. Pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade, which this patient has, may require emergency pericardiocentesis, not needle thoracostomy.

E) CORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography is a quick, inexpensive, side-effect-free, and reliable method for detecting pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. This imaging technique typically shows an anechoic space between the pericardium and epicardium, indicating fluid accumulation. In a hemodynamically unstable patient like this one, an eFAST examination in the trauma bay is likely to reveal effusion; transthoracic echocardiography is used to evaluate the size and hemodynamic effect of the effusion and determine the best approach for draining the effusion. In patients with hemodynamic instability and evidence of cardiac tamponade on echocardiography, urgent pericardial fluid drainage (e.g., ultrasound-guided pericardiocentesis) is indicated.
Image Description:

Echocardiography transthoracic (apical view; A: without needle; B and C: with needle)

Anechoic pericardial effusion (PE) was identified. Needle position (arrows) was continuously monitored while the pericardial space was entered to drain the effusion.

Arrowheads: myocardium
questions.hint: This patient presents with dyspnea and Beck triad (hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and distended neck veins) following chest trauma. Additionally, ECG shows electric alternans. These features are consistent with cardiac tamponade caused by a large pericardial effusion (due to hemopericardium).

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening shortness of breath for 6 hours. For the past 5 days, he has had intermittent stabbing pain in the middle of his chest that worsens with lying down or taking deep breaths. He has also had a runny nose and a dry cough for the past 2 weeks. He has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 34 years. His current medications include atorvastatin, enalapril, and hydrochlorothiazide. He appears pale and sweaty. His temperature is 38.3째C (100.9째F), pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 25/min. Blood pressure is 107/72 mm Hg during expiration and 86/65 mm Hg during inspiration. Examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema below the knees. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

choices.text: Dilation of the atria and ventricles
Accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavity
Tear in the inner layer of the aorta
Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the atria and ventricles is characteristic of a number of cardiac diseases, including dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). DCM can manifest with both right heart failure (jugular vein distention, peripheral edema) and left heart failure (hypotension, dyspnea) and it is commonly preceded by a recent history of viral upper respiratory infection. However, an episode of stabbing chest pain with inspiration, which was followed by worsening shortness of breath and pulsus paradoxus and preceded by flu-like symptoms, makes a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavity (pleural effusion) can occur in a variety of conditions, including congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, and nephrotic syndrome, as well as infections and malignancies. Depending on the underlying disease, pleural effusion can manifest with pleuritic chest pain (worsening with inspiration), dry cough, progressive dyspnea, jugular vein distention, and peripheral edema. However, this patient lacks other typical features of pleural effusion, such as decreased breath sounds, dullness on percussion, and asymmetrical chest expansion. Furthermore, pulsus paradoxus would not be consistent with pleural effusion.

C) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery occlusion is characteristic of myocardial infarction (MI), which can manifest with chest pain, dyspnea, tachycardia, and sweating. Moreover, acute ventricular dysfunction as a result of MI could result in peripheral edema, jugular venous distention, and hypotension. This patient's history of smoking, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia puts him at increased risk for MI. The chest pain in acute MI, however, is often described as squeezing and typically radiates to the jaw or left arm. Moreover, the combination of an episode of stabbing chest pain with inspiration and pulsus paradoxus in this patient, which was preceded by flu-like symptoms, makes a different diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

A tear in the inner layer of the aorta is characteristic of aortic dissection, which can manifest with stabbing chest pain, progressive dyspnea, pallor, and sweating. Although high blood pressure is a more common finding in patients with aortic dissection, patients may have low blood pressure if the dissection involves the proximal ascending aorta, or if it results in aortic rupture and hemorrhage. This patient's history of smoking, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia puts him at increased risk for aortic dissection. The chest pain in aortic dissection, however, is described as sudden, severe, and tearing, with radiation to the back. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical features of aortic dissection, such as asymmetrical blood pressure and pulse readings between limbs, syncope, and confusion.

E) CORRECT:

Preceded by an episode of flu-like symptoms, this patient's history of chest pain that increases with respiration and decreases while sitting up is suggestive of acute pericarditis. This patient most likely has cardiac tamponade as a complication of acute pericarditis. Cardiac tamponade can occur if increased amounts of inflammatory fluid are secreted into the pericardial space, compressing the cardiac chambers. This leads to decreased ventricular diastolic filling and decreased cardiac output. Other common causes of cardiac tamponade include aortic dissection and chest trauma.

Hemodynamically unstable patients should be treated with ultrasound-guided pericardiocentesis or surgical drainage in order to decompress the pericardium.

F) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of a pulmonary artery is characteristic of pulmonary embolism (PE), which can manifest with pleuritic chest pain (worsening with inspiration) and progressive dyspnea. Moreover, right heart failure as a result of PE would result in peripheral edema and jugular venous distention. However, a history of symptoms of upper respiratory infection, followed by an episode of intermittent sharp chest pain and pulsus paradoxus (which is rarely seen in patients with PE), is more suggestive of a different diagnosis. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical features of PE, such as cough, decreased breath sounds, symptoms of deep vein thrombosis, or a history of recent immobilization.

G) INCORRECT:

Fibrous thickening of the pericardium is characteristic of constrictive pericarditis, which can occur as a complication of acute pericarditis. Constrictive pericarditis can manifest with signs of both right heart failure (jugular vein distention, peripheral edema) and left heart failure (hypotension, dyspnea), as well as pulsus paradoxus. However, chest pain is not a typical finding in patients with constrictive pericarditis. Moreover, the patient lacks other typical features of constrictive pericarditis, such as fatigue and a pericardial knock on auscultation. Additionally, constrictive pericarditis is usually a late complication of acute pericarditis and would not be expected only 5 days after the onset of symptoms.
questions.hint: Pulsus paradoxus (significant decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration) and symptoms of heart failure (worsening shortness of breath, jugular venous distention, peripheral edema) suggest a particular condition.

questions.text: Four days after undergoing emergency pericardiocentesis, a 62-year-old woman is evaluated for worsening shortness of breath and retrosternal chest pain. The symptoms are worst when she is lying down. She also has swelling in her legs. She has squamous cell lung cancer, for which she has been receiving chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide for the past month. She also has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. Her temperature is 37.5째C (99.5째F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention. Breath sounds are mildly decreased and heart sounds are muffled. Extremities are warm and there is pitting edema at both ankles. An x-ray of the chest shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette as well as opacities and cavitary lung lesions in the left middle lung zone. Serum studies show a slightly elevated troponin concentration, a creatinine concentration of 2.2 mg/dL, and urea nitrogen concentration of 45 mg/dL. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia with low QRS voltage. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serial echocardiography (e.g., every five to seven days) can be used to monitor patients with pericardial effusion who are asymptomatic and show no signs of hemodynamic compromise. However, this patient presents with signs and symptoms that suggest cardiac tamponade, which, untreated, can progress to acute heart failure. Therefore, a conservative approach is not appropriate.

B) CORRECT:

Creating a pericardial window is the most appropriate treatment for this hemodynamically stable patient with recurrent pericardial effusion. In this surgical procedure, part of the pericardium is removed to continuously drain excess fluid from the pericardial space into the pleural cavity, providing pericardial decompression. Pericardial window is often indicated in recurrent malignant pericardial effusion because it prevents the reaccumulation of fluid and, therefore, offers definitive treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Administering sublingual nitroglycerin is indicated for the treatment of angina pectoris, which manifests with symptoms such as chest pain and shortness of breath. Although this patient is known to have coronary heart disease, her history of lung cancer and recent pericardiocentesis, as well as evidence of cardiac tamponade, indicate recurrent malignant pericardial effusion. Vasodilators, such as nitrates, should be avoided in patients with cardiac tamponade to prevent hypotension and hemodynamic instability.

D) INCORRECT:

Administering intravenous furosemide is indicated in patients with congestive heart failure, which often manifests with symptoms such as shortness of breath, chest pain, and orthopnea. However, this patient's history of lung cancer and recent pericardiocentesis, as well as evidence of cardiac tamponade, indicate recurrent malignant pericardial effusion. Diuretics should be avoided in patients with cardiac tamponade to prevent hypovolemia and hemodynamic instability.

E) INCORRECT:

Colchicine is indicated for the treatment of acute pericarditis because it alleviates symptoms and reduces the rate of recurrence. Acute pericarditis typically manifests with low-grade fever, pleuritic chest pain, and pericardial friction rub on auscultation, none of which are seen in this patient. An ECG would show diffuse, concave-shaped ST elevations with or without PR depression. Although acute pericarditis can potentially cause pericardial effusion, this patient's history of lung cancer and recent pericardiocentesis suggest recurrent malignant pericardial effusion. Furthermore, colchicine is relatively contraindicated in patients with renal insufficiency.

F) INCORRECT:

Chemotherapeutic agents, such as doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide, are associated with increased risk for pericarditis and pericardial effusion. Cisplatin, however, is not known to cause pericardial effusion. Discontinuing this drug would neither treat this patient's current condition nor prevent recurrent pericardial effusions.
questions.hint: This patient with lung cancer has dyspnea, orthopnea, muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins, low-voltage QRS complexes and tachycardia on ECG, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette. This presentation suggests cardiac tamponade secondary to recurrent malignant pericardial effusion.

questions.text: Two weeks after undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery for acute myocardial infarction, a 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of fever, sharp chest pain, and progressive fatigue. Initially, the pain was only present when he was lying supine, but now it is constant and only subsides when he leans forward. He has hypertension and mild mitral regurgitation. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 44 years but quit prior to surgery. Current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, captopril, and atorvastatin. His temperature is 38.3째C (102째F), pulse is 84/min and regular, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 132/86 mm Hg. During inspiration, the patient's blood pressure drops to 117/80 mm Hg. On physical examination, there are jugular venous pulsations 4 cm above the sternal angle. Heart sounds are faint. There is 2+ edema in the lower extremities. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased pressure in the pericardial space

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mean aortic pressure is typically increased in patients with hypertension, which is one of the most common risk factors for congestive heart failure (CHF). CHF can manifest with increased JVP and peripheral edema. However, this patient's normal blood pressure readings make this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular volume overload can be seen in cases of mitral regurgitation (MR) or aortic regurgitation (AR). While MR and AR complicated by congestive heart failure can manifest with peripheral edema and raised jugular venous pressure, this patient's presentation and findings (pulsus paradoxus, muffled heart sounds) cannot be explained by these diagnoses. Furthermore, he lacks the typical holosystolic apical murmur of MR or blowing, decrescendo early diastolic murmur of AR, respectively.

C) INCORRECT:

Postpericardiotomy syndrome is often accompanied by pericardial effusion, which would lead to decreased ventricular compliance.

D) CORRECT:

Postpericardiotomy syndrome typically manifests 16 weeks after cardiothoracic surgery as a result of an autoimmune inflammatory process in the pericardium. This syndrome may be accompanied by pericardial effusion, which can lead to cardiac tamponade, manifesting with muffled heart sounds and pulsus paradoxus. Fluid accumulation in the pericardial space leads to compression of the heart (especially the right ventricle because of its thin wall). This compression results in a shift of the interventricular septum toward the left ventricle and impaired left ventricular diastolic filling (decreased preload). Cardiac output subsequently decreases and symptoms of backward heart failure (e.g., peripheral edema and jugular venous distension due to right-sided heart failure) and forward heart failure (e.g., progressive fatigue) develop.

Pericardial effusion causing cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition that requires drainage of the pericardial fluid (e.g., using pericardiocentesis).

E) INCORRECT:

Postpericardiotomy syndrome is often accompanied by pericardial effusion, which would lead to increased pressure of the pericardial space due to the limited elasticity of the pericardium.

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased right ventricular contractility can result from the myocytes loss that accompanies right-sided myocardial infarctions (MIs). Although MIs complicated by right heart failure can result in edema and elevated jugular venous pressure, this patient's other findings (pulsus paradoxus, muffled heart sounds) make the diagnosis of postpericardiotomy syndrome more likely.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of fatigue, fever, and chest pain that is relieved by leaning forward two weeks after cardiothoracic surgery indicates postpericardiotomy syndrome. This syndrome can be complicated by pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the sudden onset of severe pain in the middle of his chest. He describes the pain as tearing in quality; it radiates to his jaw. He is sweating profusely. He has a 5-year history of hypertension and was diagnosed with chronic bronchitis 3 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 33 years. Current medications include enalapril and formoterol. The patient appears agitated. His pulse is 104/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 154/98 mm Hg in his right arm and 186/108 mm Hg in his left arm. An x-ray of the chest shows moderate hyperinflation; the mediastinum has a width of 9 cm. An ECG shows no abnormalities. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?

choices.text: Systolic murmur along the left sternal border
Diminished breath sounds over the right lung base

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tactile crepitus over the neck is a sign of subcutaneous emphysema. Spontaneous subcutaneous emphysema can occur following spontaneous esophageal rupture (Boerhaave syndrome), which can manifest with acute-onset chest pain and mediastinal widening (due to a pneumomediastinum). However, Boerhaave syndrome is usually preceded by a history of vomiting and/or severe retching, and features such as asymmetrical blood pressure readings are not be expected.

B) CORRECT:

Muffled heart sounds are a sign of cardiac tamponade, a possible complication of ascending aortic dissection (Stanford type A) due to progression of the dissection beyond the aortic root. If the dissection results in a tear of the tunica externa, aortic blood can leak into the pericardium. Pericardial fluid will decrease the transmission of heart sounds to the precordium.

Other possible complications of ascending aortic dissections include myocardial infarction (due to coronary artery occlusion), aortic regurgitation (extension of the dissection into the aortic valve), and stroke (extension of the dissection into the carotids).

C) INCORRECT:

A pericardial knock is an early diastolic sound that is associated with constrictive pericarditis. An aortic dissection can result in acute pericarditis, which, in turn, can cause constrictive pericarditis. However, a different complication (and therefore, a different clinical manifestation) is much more likely in a patient with aortic dissection.

D) INCORRECT:

An aortic dissection that involves the ascending aorta can progress proximally to the aortic root and cause aortic regurgitation (AR), which would manifest with a diastolic rather than a systolic murmur. Moreover, in patients with AR resulting from aortic root disease (e.g., aortic dissection), the murmur is best heard along the right sternal border.

E) INCORRECT:

A high-frequency midsystolic click is a characteristic finding in mitral valve prolapse (MVP), which may occur acutely after myocardial infarction. Myocardial infarction can cause chest pain that radiates to the jaw. However, the tearing nature of chest pain, the presence of asymmetric blood pressure readings, and a normal ECG are more consistent with aortic dissection, which is not associated with MVP.

F) INCORRECT:

An early-diastolic plop is a pathognomonic sign for atrial myxoma, which does have a peak incidence between 4060 years. However, myxomas typically occur among women and usually present as episodes of syncope, dyspnea, and/or palpitations, unlike this patient who presents with sudden-onset chest pain. Also, asymmetrical blood pressure readings would not be expected with myxomas.

G) INCORRECT:

Diminished breath sounds over the right lung base can be seen with pleural effusion. Extension of the aortic dissection to involve the thoracic descending aorta can result in pleural effusion. However, the left lung rather than the right lung would usually be affected.
questions.hint: Sudden and severe tearing pain, asymmetrical blood pressure readings, and a widened mediastinum on chest x-ray are consistent with aortic dissection. Uncontrolled hypertension and chronic smoking are independent risk factors for aortic dissection. The moderate pulmonary hyperinflation in this patient is not the result of aortic dissection but caused by the concomitant COPD.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 10 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest just below the clavicle. On arrival, he is hypotensive with rapid and shallow breathing and appears anxious and agitated. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Five minutes later, his pulse is 137/min and blood pressure is 84/47 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm single stab wound to the left chest at the 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line without active external bleeding. Cardiovascular examination shows muffled heart sounds and jugular venous distention. Breath sounds are normal bilaterally. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: A 15 mm Hg decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration
Lateral shift of the trachea toward the right side
Subcutaneous crepitus on palpation of the chest wall
Inward collapse of part of the chest with inspiration

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A > 10 mm Hg drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration is known as pulsus paradoxus, and is a sign observed in pathologies such as severe asthma, tension pneumothorax, constrictive pericarditis, and moderate and severe cardiac tamponade. In cardiac tamponade, the outward expansion of the right ventricle is limited, especially as blood flows during inspiration. This effect causes the interventricular septum to bulge into the left ventricle and together with a reduction in left ventricular filling causes a decrease in stroke volume as well as a subsequent drop in blood pressure.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemoptysis can occur in conditions such as tuberculosis and pulmonary contusion. Although this patient exhibits some features consistent with pulmonary contusion (tachycardia, rapid breathing), this condition is not associated with muffled heart sounds or jugular venous distention. Also, the nature of his trauma makes this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Tracheal deviation toward the contralateral side of a lesion indicates a tension pneumothorax. Although tension pneumothorax can also be caused by penetrating chest trauma, and the patient has some features of this condition, such as tachycardia, hypotension, and jugular venous distention, he does not have the key finding of reduced/absent breath sounds on the side of the lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous emphysema or crepitus on palpation of the chest wall suggests either bronchial rupture, esophageal rupture, or pneumothorax, which also may be caused by penetrating trauma. None of these conditions cause muffled heart sounds.

E) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing such as inward collapse with inspiration, suggests flail chest, which is usually caused by severe blunt thoracic trauma rather than penetrating chest trauma. Although this patient has shallow breathing, which can be a feature of flail chest, the condition is not associated with muffled heart sounds or jugular venous distention. Also, it is unlikely that a single stab wound would cause several rib fractures.
Image Description:

Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.
questions.hint: Muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and jugular venous distention (also known as Beck's triad) indicate that this patient likely has cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 12 hours after the sudden onset of shortness of breath and substernal chest pain at rest; the pain is increased by inspiration. He has also had a nonproductive cough, fever, and malaise for the past 5 days. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. His temperature is 38째C (100.4째F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows distended neck veins. Auscultation of the chest discloses bilateral basilar rales and muffled heart sounds. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia, diffuse ST segment elevation, low voltage QRS complexes, and fluctuating R wave amplitude. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Post-infarction fibrinous pericarditis typically occurs 13 days after a transmural myocardial infarction (MI) and can manifest with fever, inspiratory chest pain, dry cough, and diffuse ST elevation, as seen in this patient. However, this patient does not have a history of coronary artery disease or recent MI, making post-infarction fibrinous pericarditis unlikely. Rather, his 5-day history of cough, fever, and malaise suggests an infectious cause for the pericarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease manifests with fever and malaise, as seen in this patient. Myocarditis and myocardial infarction are known complications of this condition that can manifest with chest pain and features of cardiac decompensation (e.g., dyspnea, bilateral rales, distended neck veins). However, a diagnosis of Kawasaki disease requires further specific symptoms, such as erythema and edema of the hands and feet, polymorphous rash, conjunctivitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, and oropharyngeal mucositis. Moreover, this condition most commonly affects children under the age of 5 years, so it is an unlikely diagnosis in a 55-year-old man.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic fever (RF) manifests with fever and malaise, as seen in this patient. Cardiac complications of RF include pancarditis and valvular heart disease, which can cause symptoms of cardiac decompensation (e.g., dyspnea, bilateral rales, distended neck veins). However, the typical ECG finding in RF is a prolonged PR interval, which is not seen here. Moreover, this patient does not have a history of untreated bacterial tonsillopharyngitis or other typical features of RF (e.g., migratory polyarthritis, subcutaneous nodules, erythema marginatum, Sydenham chorea).

D) INCORRECT:

Dressler syndrome usually occurs 210 weeks after myocardial infarction (MI) due to immune complex-mediated damage in the pericardium. While this patient does present with signs and symptoms of acute pericarditis (e.g., fever, pleuritic chest pain, dry cough, and diffuse ST elevation), he does not have a history of coronary artery disease or past MI, making Dressler syndrome unlikely. Rather, his 5-day history of cough, fever, and malaise suggests an infectious cause for the pericarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

Infective endocarditis (IE) could explain this patient's fever, malaise, pleuritic chest pain, and features of cardiac decompensation (e.g., dyspnea, bilateral rales, distended neck veins). However, he presents with muffled heart sounds rather than a new murmur, which is a key manifestation of IE, and he does not have extracardiac manifestations of IE (e.g., splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, and Roth spots). Additionally, his ECG findings suggest another diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade, a complication of acute pericarditis, is caused by the combination of increased secretion of fluid into pericardial space and decreased elasticity of the pericardium secondary to inflammation. Once the pericardial effusion becomes sufficiently pronounced, either due to the rate of fluid accumulation or the amount of fluid, the heart can become compressed, which decreases cardiac output and ventricular diastolic filling. This patient presents with the classic symptoms of cardiac tamponade: hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds (i.e., Beck triad) as well as a characteristic ECG finding of low-voltage QRS complexes and fluctuating R wave amplitude (i.e., electrical alternans).
questions.hint: A 12-hour history of dyspnea and inspiratory chest pain in the setting of a 5-day prodrome of subjective fever, malaise, and dry cough suggests an acute infection of the pericardium.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after a restrained motor vehicle crash. She reports chest pressure and shortness of breath. She has no medical history and takes no prescription medications. She is lethargic on examination but responds to painful stimuli.
She has a blood pressure of 85/60 mm Hg (equal in both arms), a heart rate of 105 beats per minute that is regular, a respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 96% while breathing ambient air.
Her anterior chest is tender to palpation but without notable fractures. She has symmetric chest wall movement on inhalation and expiration and bilateral breath sounds without tracheal deviation. Her heart sounds are muffled, and her jugular veins are notably elevated without lower-extremity edema. Her abdomen is soft, nondistended, and nontender.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The features of acute cardiac tamponade include hypotension, distended neck veins, and distant, muffled heart sounds. A minority of patients with acute cardiac tamponade present with all three features; their presence together is highly suggestive of the diagnosis. The enlarged cardiac silhouette seen on the chest radiograph is consistent with a pericardial effusion.

Key learning point: The acute findings of hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated jugular venous pressure in a trauma patient are most indicative of the diagnosis of acute cardiac tamponade.

B) INCORRECT:

A flail chest is a life-threatening condition when several ribs are broken in multiple locations, invariably involving pulmonary contusions, which may decrease oxygenation. The characteristic findings include paradoxical motion of the affected ribs (i.e., they move in opposition with the patients respiratory cycle). The chest radiograph shows no evidence of rib fractures.

C) INCORRECT:

An aortic dissection is less likely, given that the patients mediastinum is not enlarged and her upper-extremity blood pressures are equivalent.

D) INCORRECT:

An acute pulmonary contusion manifests with chest pain, hemoptysis, and hypoxemia. It is not typically associated with an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

E) INCORRECT:

The patient has bilateral breath sounds with normal oxygenation and a midline trachea, which would not be expected with a tension pneumothorax. Furthermore, the chest radiograph does not show a pneumothorax or tracheal deviation.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset dyspnea and confusion. She is unable to provide an adequate history, but her family reports progressive dyspnea during the past 24 hours. When she showed signs of confusion, the family called an ambulance.
Physical examination of the patient reveals a regular heart rate of 120 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, an oxygen saturation of 95% while breathing ambient air, and a blood pressure of 85/55 mm Hg, with variation in the systolic blood pressure of approximately 15 mm Hg during the respiratory cycle.
Jugular venous pulsations are appreciated up to the angle of the jaw with the patient recumbent at 45 degrees. Cardiac auscultation detects faint heart sounds without a murmur or friction rub. Lungs are clear on auscultation. The extremities are cool to the touch, without appreciable edema.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A chest radiograph reveals an enlarged cardiac silhouette with normal lung parenchyma. An electrocardiogram is shown (figure).
Which one of the following immediate therapeutic interventions is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Bolus infusion of 1 liter of normal saline

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An inotropic agent, such as dobutamine, is unlikely to improve hemodynamic variables in the setting of normal cardiac systolic function.

B) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol would reduce the heart rate, thereby worsening systemic hypoperfusion, given that the tachycardia is a compensatory response to a diminished stroke volume in the setting of reduced diastolic filling.

C) INCORRECT:

Diuresis with furosemide is inappropriate in a hypotensive patient with features of cardiac tamponade.

D) INCORRECT:

Norepinephrine is not likely to be effective until right-sided filling pressures are increased by administering fluids.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has a clinical profile that suggests cardiac tamponade: hypotension, tachycardia, pulsus paradoxus, elevated jugular venous pressure, faint heart sounds, clear lung fields on chest radiograph, and signs of peripheral hypoperfusion (cool extremities). The enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest radiograph, together with the electrocardiographic evidence of electrical alternans (variability in QRS amplitude and axis due to swinging of the heart within the pericardial fluid), is consistent with a large pericardial effusion. Malignancy is one of many potential causes of pericardial effusion.

The first step in managing cardiac tamponade is aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation, accompanied by a transthoracic echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis and, if an effusion is noted, an urgent needle pericardiocentesis or pericardial window.

Key learning point: The first step in managing a patient with hemodynamic instability and suspected cardiac tamponade should be aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation. This step should be accompanied by an urgent transthoracic echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis and by consideration for immediate therapeutic pericardiocentesis or pericardial window.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman is transferred to the cardiac intensive care unit for monitoring after successful percutaneous radiofrequency ablation of a supraventricular tachycardia. Her heart rate is 78 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg, her respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute, her oxygen saturation is 98% while breathing ambient air, and her central venous pressure is normal.
Shortly after transfer, she becomes acutely tachypneic and hypotensive, with a systolic blood pressure of 76 mm Hg. Her Korotkoff sounds are inaudible during inspiration. She has marked jugular venous distention and equal breath sounds without rales. Her femoral access site shows no evidence of a hematoma. Her electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia at 126 beats per minute. An intravenous bolus of normal saline is initiated.
Which one of the following diagnostic studies is most likely to show the cause of this patients clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism and acute myocardial infarction are unlikely complications immediately after a catheter ablation procedure in an otherwise healthy young woman; thus, pulmonary CT angiography and measurement of cardiac enzymes are not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypotension from acute blood loss would be characterized by low, rather than elevated, central venous pressure. Therefore, measurement of hemoglobin and hematocrit is inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

A chest radiograph is unlikely to provide information of sufficient specificity to guide treatment in this case. An acute, rapidly accumulating pericardial effusion does not typically cause a large heart (i.e., enlarged cardiac silhouette) on chest radiograph.

D) CORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade caused by perforation of the myocardium is a recognized complication of cardiac ablation procedures. It is the most likely diagnosis in a patient who develops hypotension, pulsus paradoxus, sinus tachycardia, and elevated central venous pressure after the procedure. The diagnosis can be confirmed rapidly by bedside echocardiography, which would be followed by urgent pericardiocentesis.

Key learning point: Hypotension and elevated jugular venous pressure after a cardiac ablation procedure suggests a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade, which requires urgent bedside echocardiography and pericardiocentesis.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism and acute myocardial infarction are unlikely complications immediately after a catheter ablation procedure in an otherwise healthy young woman; thus, pulmonary CT angiography and measurement of cardiac enzymes are not indicated.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of dyspnea, dizziness, and pain in his chest and left shoulder. Approximately 2 weeks ago, he underwent an uneventful, minimally invasive aortic valve replacement for a bicuspid aortic valve.
His current temperature is 37.9째C, and his heart rate is 118 beats per minute. His blood pressure is 85/60 mm Hg in both arms, with a 15 mm Hg decline in systolic pressure on inspiration. He appears to be very uncomfortable and in pain. He has jugular venous distention when sitting upright and cannot lie flat or take deep breaths because of worsening shoulder pain. Cardiac auscultation reveals distant first and second heart sounds without murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A postoperative chest radiograph from 2 weeks ago is compared to a current radiograph (figure).
Which one of the following diagnostic steps should be taken next in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography is not the best next step in this patient. It is an invasive procedure, and myocardial ischemia is not the most likely diagnosis with this clinical presentation.

B) CORRECT:

This patient with recent cardiac surgery has hypotension, pulsus paradoxus, low-grade fever, tachycardia, systemic venous congestion, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest radiograph. Subacute cardiac tamponade, the most likely explanation for the findings, can occur after cardiac surgery due to inflammation of the pericardium. Transthoracic echocardiography can confirm the diagnosis rapidly and guide needle pericardiocentesis, if indicated; transesophageal echocardiography is not necessary for this purpose.

Key learning point: Two weeks after undergoing aortic valve repair, a patient presents with shortness of breath, hypotension with an additional fall in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, jugular venous distention, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest radiograph. The most appropriate diagnostic test is transthoracic echocardiography.

C) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography and aortography are appropriate for diagnosing aortic dissection, but the clinical presentation is more consistent with pericardial tamponade.

D) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography and aortography are appropriate for diagnosing aortic dissection, but the clinical presentation is more consistent with pericardial tamponade.

E) INCORRECT:

Although postoperative pulmonary embolism should be considered in a patient who is hypotensive, tachycardic, and tachypneic, the radiograph findings suggest an enlarged cardiac silhouette consistent with a pericardial effusion, which would not be expected with a pulmonary embolism.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman presents to the emergency department reporting a 24-hour history of progressive chest discomfort and shortness of breath. She was diagnosed with invasive breast cancer 4 weeks ago and is currently undergoing staging evaluation as an outpatient.
On examination, she has a heart rate of 120 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 84/52 mm Hg. She has an elevated jugular venous pressure, clear lungs, and cool extremities.
She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A chest radiograph shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette with clear lungs. An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following physical findings is this patient most likely to have?

choices.text: A friction rub heard over the cardiac apex
A decrease in systolic blood pressure of at least 10 mm Hg on inspiration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A friction rub heard at the apex is typical of pericarditis but not necessarily pericardial effusion with tamponade.

B) INCORRECT:

In cardiac tamponade, the jugular venous pressure is usually elevated because of restricted filling of the right atrium and ventricle.

C) INCORRECT:

A left ventricular third heart sound (S3) is unlikely in this patient with clear lungs and a presentation more consistent with tamponade than with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

D) CORRECT:

The combination of a large heart with hypotension, clear lungs on chest radiograph, and electrical alternans on electrocardiogram suggests cardiac tamponade. Acute management for hemodynamically unstable cardiac tamponade includes aggressive intravenous fluids and urgent pericardiocentesis or surgical drainage.

A characteristic clinical finding in a patient with cardiac tamponade is pulsus paradoxus. Pulsus paradoxus is defined by a decrease in systolic blood pressure of at least 10 mm Hg on inspiration, an exaggeration of the normal hemodynamic response. Inspiration is accompanied by a decrease in intrathoracic pressure, which increases venous return. Given that the right ventricular free wall cannot expand (because of the increased pericardial pressure), the increased venous return to the right ventricle shifts the interventricular septum leftward. This septal shift reduces left ventricular filling and, consequently, lowers systemic stroke volume and blood pressure. Note that pulsus paradoxus can also occur in asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Key learning point: Pulsus paradoxus, commonly seen in patients with cardiac tamponade, refers to an exaggeration of a normal hemodynamic response to inspiration, whereby the systolic blood pressure decreases by at least 10 mm Hg.

E) INCORRECT:

A loud second pulmonary sound is most indicative of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man with stage IV adenocarcinoma of the lung with pericardial metastases on palliative chemotherapy reports one month of progressive shortness of breath. One month ago, he was successfully treated for cardiac tamponade with pericardiocentesis that involved removal of 300 cc of serosanguineous fluid.
The patient has a current heart rate of 95 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 100/70 mm Hg, and a decrease in systolic blood pressure of 8 mm Hg during inspiration. His jugular venous pressure is mildly elevated, and his heart sounds are muffled.
A chest radiograph reveals an enlarged cardiac silhouette. Transthoracic echocardiography confirms the presence of a recurrent large pericardial effusion.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for managing this patients pericardial effusion?

choices.text: Repeat pericardiocentesis with an indwelling catheter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radiation or systemic chemotherapy is a reasonable option in a patient with malignancy that is highly responsive to such treatment, but adenocarcinoma of the lung is usually relatively unresponsive to those approaches. Chemotherapy and radiotherapy are typically used in conjunction with a definitive drainage procedure.

B) CORRECT:

Malignant pericardial effusions recur in approximately 20% to 50% of cases after initial treatment with pericardiocentesis. Surgical subxiphoid pericardiotomy (or a pericardial window) is a highly safe, effective, minimally invasive procedure for recurrent pericardial effusions. It can usually be performed under local anesthesia and, therefore, is the treatment of choice for recurrent malignant pericardial effusions.

Key learning point: Patients with recurrent malignant pericardial effusions are best treated with surgical subxiphoid pericardiotomy.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeat pericardiocentesis, although acutely effective, does not provide the definitive management (i.e., continued drainage) offered by subxiphoid pericardiotomy.

D) INCORRECT:

The addition of an indwelling catheter may be more effective than pericardiocentesis alone, but it can be used only for very short-term management given the risks for severe infection and catheter occlusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Thoracotomy with pericardiectomy is an effective procedure, but it is substantially more invasive than subxiphoid pericardiotomy, requires general anesthesia, and is associated with a higher perioperative risk.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman is admitted with a 2-week history of progressive dyspnea, orthopnea, chest pain without exertion, and a mild, nonproductive cough. She denies any fever.
Two years ago, she was diagnosed with stage III invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast that had the following immunohistochemical profile: estrogen-receptor-negative, progesterone-receptor-negative, and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2positive. She was treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy consisting of docetaxel, carboplatin, and trastuzumab, followed by surgery, radiation, and one year of trastuzumab, which she completed one year ago.
Upon admission, her blood pressure is 90/70 mm Hg, her heart rate is 110 beats per minute, her jugular venous pressure is measured at a height of 10 cm, and she has muffled heart sounds. She does not have lung crackles or pedal edema.
Laboratory testing shows a normal complete blood count, a normal D-dimer level, and negative cardiac enzymes. An electrocardiogram shows low voltage and a sinus tachycardia.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute viral myocarditis is unlikely because of the absence of clinical or electrocardiographic signs of myocarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

Trastuzumab-induced cardiomyopathy usually manifests as a congestive heart failure syndrome and is unlikely to occur one year after the end of trastuzumab therapy. Clinical trials have shown cardiotoxic effects in 27% of patients treated concurrently with trastuzumab and anthracyclines, 13% of those treated with trastuzumab and paclitaxel, and 5% of those treated with trastuzumab alone.

C) CORRECT:

Malignant pericardial effusion should be suspected in a patient with cancer who presents with progressive dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia, and Beck triad (low systolic blood pressure, jugular venous distention, and muffled heart sounds). An echocardiogram should be performed to rule out cardiac tamponade, which would require urgent pericardiocentesis, a pericardial window, or both.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with likely recurrent breast cancer who presents with progressive dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia, low systolic blood pressure with low pulse pressure, jugular venous distention, and muffled heart sounds is malignant pericardial effusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism would not be associated with muffled heart sounds.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient with restrictive cardiomyopathy, physical examination findings would also be consistent with right heart failure, including peripheral edema, hepatomegaly, and ascites. In addition, the patient would likely have normal (rather than muffled) heart sounds.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman with recently diagnosed invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast presents to the emergency department reporting 3 days of progressive fatigue, shortness of breath, and chest discomfort. Her medical history is significant for stage II Hodgkin lymphoma, which was treated with mantle field radiation when she was 16, and a 5-year history of hypertension. Her current medications include lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide.
On physical examination, she is afebrile and has a blood pressure of 85/67 mm Hg, a heart rate of 125 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. Cardiac examination reveals no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. She has a pulsus paradoxus of 12 mm Hg; jugular venous pressure is estimated at 12 cm of water. Her lungs are clear on auscultation, and she has no pedal edema.
An electrocardiogram reveals sinus tachycardia. An echocardiogram shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 65%, a small-to-moderate anterior pericardial effusion, and early diastolic right ventricular collapse.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The physical finding of pulsus paradoxus can be seen in both constrictive pericarditis and cardiac tamponade, but it is more common with tamponade than with constrictive pericarditis. Clinically, patients with constrictive pericarditis tend to present with fatigue, dyspnea, and peripheral edema. An elevated jugular venous pressure and pericardial rub may be present as well. Although this patients history of mantle field radiation for lymphoma places her at high risk for constrictive pericarditis, the early diastolic RV collapse seen on echocardiogram and the acuity of her symptoms are more consistent with cardiac tamponade.

B) INCORRECT:

The clinical presentation and echocardiographic findings are not typical for acutely presenting primary heart failure with preserved ejection fraction.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation and echocardiographic findings are consistent with cardiac tamponade from malignant pericardial effusion. The lack of a large effusion does not rule out tamponade. Early diastolic right ventricular (RV) collapse on echocardiogram has 85% to 100% specificity for cardiac tamponade. In tamponade, the intrapericardial pressure transiently exceeds the RV filling pressure, leading to collapse of the right ventricle and hemodynamic compromise.

Key learning point: A specific echocardiographic sign of pericardial tamponade in a patient with a malignant effusion is diastolic right ventricular collapse.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient currently has cancer and is therefore at increased risk for pulmonary embolism. However, her echocardiogram does not show features of submassive or massive pulmonary embolism, such as a hypokinetic, dilated RV.

E) INCORRECT:

Pericardial effusions can develop in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension. However, this is usually a chronically progressive condition and is associated with echocardiographic findings such as RV dilation, RV systolic dysfunction, and tricuspid regurgitation.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) after presenting to the emergency department with tachycardia, hypotension, and dyspnea, with concerns for sepsis. He was given intravenous fluid boluses, and parenteral antibiotics were started.
On his arrival to the PICU, he reports difficulty breathing and chest tightness, which he says improves when he sits forward. His vital signs are significant for a heart rate of 145 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 75/40 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while he breathes ambient air. On examination, he has poor perfusion with a capillary refill time of 5 seconds. His lungs are clear to auscultation.
Which one of the following management steps will result in the best outcome for this patient?

choices.text: Give a dose of intravenous ketorolac

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Milrinone is an inodilator that causes increased inotropy, lusitropy, and vasodilation. It is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor and can help improve cardiac output in cardiogenic shock; its main adverse effect is hypotension. Given that this patient is already hypotensive, milrinone would not be appropriate, as it could worsen his hypotension and lead to cardiac arrest. Although the patient is presenting with cardiogenic shock, urgent removal of pericardial fluid and relief of tamponade is most pressing and would be expected to improve his cardiovascular status.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with chest pain, dyspnea, and tachycardia with clinical signs of poor perfusion (hypotension, prolonged capillary refill time) consistent with cardiogenic shock. His symptoms are improved when he leans forward, consistent with pericardial effusion. The effusion has increased to the point of causing tamponade with evidence of shock, requiring emergency intervention.

Pericardial tamponade is caused by fluid in the pericardial sac, which leads to elevated pericardial pressures and compression of the chambers of the heart. This compression ultimately causes reduced systemic venous return, reduced cardiac filling, and ultimately a marked reduction in cardiac output. Patients typically present with syncope, chest pain, dyspnea, tachycardia, and jugular venous distention.

The treatment for cardiac tamponade in a patient with hemodynamic instability (e.g., hypotension) is emergency pericardiocentesis. This procedure can be done urgently at the bedside with a small-gauge needle using anatomic landmarks or with ultrasound guidance and can be lifesaving. With subacute tamponade, there might be enough time to seek out consultation from experienced clinicians who can perform the procedure with echocardiography or fluoroscopy. In this case, however, the patient is hemodynamically unstable with hypotension and poor perfusion, necessitating emergency intervention.

Key learning point: The most important next step in the management of an adolescent who has profound hypotension, dyspnea, and chest pain that improves with leaning forward is pericardiocentesis.

C) INCORRECT:

Ketorolac is a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug that is sometimes used to treat the pain associated with pericarditis. Although this patient likely has an element of pericardial pain (as suggested by mild relief with sitting forward) that could be relieved with ketorolac, he is unstable, and urgent evacuation of fluid from the pericardium is indicated before additional symptomatic treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Norepinephrine is a vasoactive agent that acts on alpha-adrenergic receptors to cause vasoconstriction and, to a lesser degree, beta-adrenergic receptors to cause increased inotropy and chronotropy. Norepinephrine would not be the first choice of vasoactive agents in cardiogenic shock given that the alpha effects are greater than the beta effects.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous fluid is indicated when the etiology of tachycardia and hypotension is due to intravascular volume depletion. In this case, the patient is exhibiting cardiogenic shock and has not improved with prior intravenous fluid boluses.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with a history of systemic lupus erythematous presents to the emergency department with chest discomfort and shortness of breath that has been worsening since this morning. She also notes that during the past week, she has had a low-grade fever of 38.1째C, cough, and congestion. She is up to date on Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
On physical examination, she has a temperature of 37.2째C, a heart rate of 154 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 85/55 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while breathing ambient air. There is increased work of breathing with tachypnea and subcostal retractions. Lung fields are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals muffled heart sounds without a murmur. The abdomen is soft, the liver is palpable 2 cm below the right costal margin, and the patient is comfortable when supine. The extremities are cool. There is no evidence of peripheral edema. Skin examination is unremarkable.
A chest radiograph and electrocardiogram are obtained (figures).
What is the most important intervention for this patient?

choices.text: Administration of a bolus of intravenous fluids

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease that can have significant cardiac involvement. The most common cardiac complication of SLE is pericarditis or myocarditis, particularly during flares. In addition, patients with SLE can develop coronary artery disease and conduction issues.

This patients examination is concerning for pericardial effusion with tamponade physiology: tachycardia, hypotension, and elevated central venous pressure. Her chest radiograph shows cardiomegaly consistent with a likely effusion. Electrical alternans is a classic finding of cardiac tamponade, whereby every other QRS complex is of smaller voltage. This finding is present in this patients electrocardiogram, best seen by comparing the voltage of the QRS complexes in the rhythm strip (arrows).

Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition caused by external compression of the heart from accumulation of fluid or air in the pericardial space. The fluid can be blood or another exudative or transudative fluid.

Pericardial effusion (without tamponade) can be nonspecific in presentation or even asymptomatic. Typically, if there is a hemodynamically significant effusion and tamponade, the patient is more symptomatic. Acute tamponade can lead to cardiogenic shock with hypotension, tachycardia, cool extremities, and tachypnea. Examination may reveal a pericardial rub or muffled heart sounds related to the insulating effects of the pericardial fluid and jugular venous distention. Affected patients often have pulsus paradoxus, an inspiratory systolic fall in arterial pressure of 10 mm Hg during normal breathing. Beck triad (hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and jugular venous distention) describes the classic signs in acute tamponade but may be present in only a minority of cases.

Treatment for cardiac tamponade involves urgent pericardiocentesis, whereby a needle is used to drain the pericardial fluid.
