This procedure can be done emergently at the bedside in the setting of rapid clinical deterioration or, alternatively, in the catheterization lab if the patient is stable for transfer. After drainage, echocardiography can be used to monitor for reaccumulation of fluid.

Supportive care with fluid resuscitation, inotropic support, or both may prove temporarily beneficial but should not be considered a substitute for drainage of the effusion.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for cardiac tamponade is urgent pericardiocentesis.

B) INCORRECT:

Coronary angiography would be indicated in the setting of a myocardial infarction. This patients presentation is consistent with cardiac tamponade, not myocardial infarction.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous (IV) fluids are unhelpful in tamponade physiology because increased preload will not overcome right atrial and ventricular compression.

D) INCORRECT:

Vasoactive medications can increase chronotropy or inotropy. These medications are likely to be ineffective in this patient, as they cannot overcome tamponade physiology.

E) INCORRECT:

IV methylprednisolone may be indicated for treatment of SLE in the setting of a flare, but it is not the most appropriate first step in this critically unstable patient.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sharp chest pain for 3 days. The pain is retrosternal, 8 out of 10 in intensity, increases with respiration, and decreases while sitting upright and leaning forward. He has nausea and myalgia. His temperature is 37.3째C (99.1째F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched grating sound between S1 and S2. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Urea nitrogen
16 mg/dl


Glucose
93 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.7 mg/dL


Troponin I
0.23 ng/mL


An ECG shows diffuse ST elevations in all leads. The patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture is a life-threatening complication of acute myocardial infarction (MI) that leads to mitral regurgitation with subsequent hypotension and pulmonary edema. Although this patient presents with chest pain, symptoms of acute MI do not usually last for three consecutive days and present with ST elevations in anatomically contiguous leads on ECG.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary infarction is most commonly caused by pulmonary embolism (PE), which can also present with chest pain and nonspecific ST elevation. However, other common features of PE would be expected, including dyspnea, tachypnea, cough, hypotension, or signs of right ventricular pressure overload on ECG (e.g., right axis deviation). The absence of these symptoms in this case, as well as the presence of a friction rub on auscultation, make pulmonary embolism and therefore pulmonary infarction unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Mediastinitis may occur as a result of esophageal disorders (e.g., Boerhaave syndrome). Patients with Boerhaave syndrome often present with a history of explosive vomiting and symptoms such as retrosternal pain and mediastinal emphysema (Mackler triad). The retrosternal pain seen in this patient makes Boerhaave syndrome an important differential diagnosis. However, in this case, the patient's history, auscultatory and ECG findings are suggestive of a different disease.

D) CORRECT:

Pericarditis is a common cause of cardiac tamponade; it may occur in cases in which the pericardium becomes scarred and less elastic, while increased amounts of inflammatory fluids are secreted into the pericardial space. Cardiac tamponade can lead to hemodynamic compromise; therefore, treatment with pericardiocentesis is indicated.

Another complication of acute pericarditis is chronic, constrictive pericarditis, which may develop after several years.

E) INCORRECT:

A ventricular aneurysm is a late (> 3 weeks) complication of myocardial infarction (MI) that presents with persistent ST elevations and T wave inversions on ECG and can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and thromboembolisms. Although this patient presents with chest pain, symptoms of acute MI do not usually last for three consecutive days and present with more specific findings on ECG. Considering the timing and that MI is unlikely, ventricular aneurysm can be ruled out.
questions.hint: The patient's 3-day history of chest pain that increases with respiration and decreases while sitting up, in conjunction with a friction rub on cardiac auscultation, nausea, and myalgia, is suggestive of acute pericarditis. The ECG finding of ST elevations in all leads with a mild increase in troponin I further support the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 10 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest just below the clavicle. On arrival, he is hypotensive with rapid and shallow breathing and appears anxious and agitated. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. An infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. Five minutes later, his pulse is 137/min and blood pressure is 84/47 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm single stab wound to the left chest at the 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line without active external bleeding. Cardiovascular examination shows muffled heart sounds and jugular venous distention. Breath sounds are normal bilaterally. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: A 15 mm Hg decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration
Lateral shift of the trachea toward the right side
Subcutaneous crepitus on palpation of the chest wall
Inward collapse of part of the chest with inspiration

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A > 10 mm Hg drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration is known as pulsus paradoxus, and is a sign observed in pathologies such as severe asthma, tension pneumothorax, constrictive pericarditis, and moderate and severe cardiac tamponade. In cardiac tamponade, the outward expansion of the right ventricle is limited, especially as blood flows during inspiration. This effect causes the interventricular septum to bulge into the left ventricle and together with a reduction in left ventricular filling causes a decrease in stroke volume as well as a subsequent drop in blood pressure.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemoptysis can occur in conditions such as tuberculosis and pulmonary contusion. Although this patient exhibits some features consistent with pulmonary contusion (tachycardia, rapid breathing), this condition is not associated with muffled heart sounds or jugular venous distention. Also, the nature of his trauma makes this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Tracheal deviation toward the contralateral side of a lesion indicates a tension pneumothorax. Although tension pneumothorax can also be caused by penetrating chest trauma, and the patient has some features of this condition, such as tachycardia, hypotension, and jugular venous distention, he does not have the key finding of reduced/absent breath sounds on the side of the lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous emphysema or crepitus on palpation of the chest wall suggests either bronchial rupture, esophageal rupture, or pneumothorax, which also may be caused by penetrating trauma. None of these conditions cause muffled heart sounds.

E) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing such as inward collapse with inspiration, suggests flail chest, which is usually caused by severe blunt thoracic trauma rather than penetrating chest trauma. Although this patient has shallow breathing, which can be a feature of flail chest, the condition is not associated with muffled heart sounds or jugular venous distention. Also, it is unlikely that a single stab wound would cause several rib fractures.
Image Description:

Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.
questions.hint: Muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and jugular venous distention (also known as Beck's triad) indicate that this patient likely has cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of dyspnea, dizziness, and pain in his chest and left shoulder. Approximately 2 weeks ago, he underwent an uneventful, minimally invasive aortic valve replacement for a bicuspid aortic valve. His pulse is 118/min and blood pressure is 85/60 mm Hg in both arms, with a 15 mm Hg decline in systolic pressure on inspiration. He has jugular venous distention when sitting upright. Cardiac auscultation reveals distant first and second heart sounds without murmurs, rubs, or gallops. A postoperative chest radiograph from 2 weeks ago is compared to a current radiograph (figure). Which one of the following diagnostic steps should be taken next in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography is not the best next step in this patient. It is an invasive procedure, and myocardial ischemia is not the most likely diagnosis with this clinical presentation.

B) CORRECT:

Subacute cardiac tamponade, the most likely explanation for the patient's findings, can occur after cardiac surgery due to inflammation of the pericardium. Transthoracic echocardiography can confirm the diagnosis rapidly and guide needle pericardiocentesis, if indicated; transesophageal echocardiography is not necessary for this purpose.

Key learning point: Two weeks after undergoing aortic valve repair, a patient presents with shortness of breath, hypotension with an additional fall in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, jugular venous distention, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest radiograph. The most appropriate diagnostic test is transthoracic echocardiography.

C) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography and aortography are appropriate for diagnosing aortic dissection, but the clinical presentation is more consistent with pericardial tamponade.

D) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography and aortography are appropriate for diagnosing aortic dissection, but the clinical presentation is more consistent with pericardial tamponade.

E) INCORRECT:

Although postoperative pulmonary embolism should be considered in a patient who is hypotensive, tachycardic, and tachypneic, the radiograph findings suggest an enlarged cardiac silhouette consistent with a pericardial effusion, which would not be expected with a pulmonary embolism.
questions.hint: Muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and jugular venous distention (also known as Beck's triad) indicate that this patient likely has cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus presents to the emergency department with chest discomfort and shortness of breath that has been worsening since this morning. She also notes that during the past week, she has had a low-grade fever of 38.1째C (100.6째F), cough, and congestion. On physical examination, her pulse is 154/min, blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg, and her oxygen saturation is 99% while breathing ambient air. There is increased work of breathing with tachypnea and subcostal retractions. Lung fields are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals muffled heart sounds without a murmur. An electrocardiogram shows low QRS voltages with electrical alternans. A chest radiograph is shown. What is the most important intervention for this patient?

choices.text: Administration of a bolus of intravenous fluids

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's examination is concerning for pericardial effusion with tamponade physiology: tachycardia, hypotension, and elevated central venous pressure. Her chest radiograph shows cardiomegaly consistent with a likely effusion. Electrical alternans is a classic finding of cardiac tamponade, whereby every other QRS complex is of smaller voltage. This finding is present in this patient's electrocardiogram, best seen by comparing the voltage of the QRS complexes in the rhythm strip (arrows).

Treatment for cardiac tamponade involves urgent pericardiocentesis, whereby a needle is used to drain the pericardial fluid. This procedure can be done emergently at the bedside in the setting of rapid clinical deterioration or, alternatively, in the catheterization lab if the patient is stable for transfer. After drainage, echocardiography can be used to monitor for reaccumulation of fluid.

Supportive care with fluid resuscitation, inotropic support, or both may prove temporarily beneficial but should not be considered a substitute for drainage of the effusion.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for cardiac tamponade is urgent pericardiocentesis.

B) INCORRECT:

Coronary angiography would be indicated in the setting of a myocardial infarction. This patient's presentation is consistent with cardiac tamponade, not myocardial infarction.

C) INCORRECT:

D) INCORRECT:

Vasoactive medications can increase chronotropy or inotropy. These medications are likely to be ineffective in this patient, as they cannot overcome tamponade physiology.

E) INCORRECT:

IV methylprednisolone may be indicated for treatment of SLE in the setting of a flare, but it is not the most appropriate first step in this critically unstable patient.
questions.hint: This patient has systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease that can have significant cardiac involvement.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest. On arrival, he has rapid, shallow breathing and appears anxious. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min and shallow, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 80 mm Hg. There is a 2.5-cm single stab wound to the left chest at the 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Cardiovascular examination shows muffled heart sounds and jugular venous distention. Breath sounds are normal. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Tracheal deviation toward the right side
A drop in systolic blood pressure of 14 mm Hg during inspiration
Herniation of the stomach into the chest
Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tracheal deviation toward the contralateral side of a lesion can occur with a tension pneumothorax or a massive hemothorax. Although both of these conditions can be caused by penetrating chest trauma and result in tachycardia, hypotension, and jugular venous distention, this patient does not have reduced breath sounds, which is a characteristic auscultatory finding in both of these conditions.

B) CORRECT:

In cardiac tamponade, outward expansion of the ventricles is limited because of fluid in the pericardial space. During inspiration, increased venous return leads to increased right ventricular volume. As outward expansion is limited, the right ventricle expands via the interventricular septum, which bulges into the left ventricle. This effect leads to further reduction in left ventricular filling during inspiration, resulting in decreased stroke volume and a subsequent drop in blood pressure. A drop in systolic blood pressure > 10 mm Hg during inspiration is known as pulsus paradoxus, a sign characteristically seen in moderate and severe cardiac tamponade but also in some cases of severe asthma, tension pneumothorax, and constrictive pericarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

Herniation of the stomach into the chest indicates diaphragmatic injury. This condition may also result after a penetrating chest trauma. Although shallow breathing is a feature consistent with diaphragmatic injury, this patient is lacking other key findings of this condition, such as chest or abdominal pain, reduced breath sounds, and bowel sounds in the chest on auscultation. In addition, muffled heart sounds would not be expected in this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous emphysema or crepitus suggests either bronchial rupture, esophageal rupture, or pneumothorax, which also may be caused by penetrating trauma. None of these conditions cause muffled heart sounds.

E) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing suggests flail chest, which is usually caused by severe blunt thoracic trauma rather than penetrating chest trauma. Although this patient has shallow breathing, which may be a feature of flail chest, the condition is not associated with muffled heart sounds or jugular venous distention, and it is unlikely that a single stab wound would cause several rib fractures.
Image Description:

Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.
questions.hint: Muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and jugular venous distention (also known as Beck triad) following penetrating chest trauma are consistent with cardiac tamponade.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with progressive shortness of breath and persistent fatigue. Over the past week, he has noticed swelling around his ankles. His medical history includes hypertension and a recent myocardial infarction. Examination shows elevated jugular venous pressure, soft heart sounds, and a pulse drop greater than 10 mmHg on inspiration. Laboratory values show normal troponin levels (see reports).

Blood pressure
90/60 mmHg


Chest radiograph: Enlarged cardiac silhouette with no evidence of pulmonary edema
ECG: Nonspecific ST-T changes; no obvious conduction abnormalities

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade manifests with elevated intrapericardial pressure that impairs cardiac diastolic filling. The triad of low blood pressure, elevated jugular venous pressure, and muffled heart sounds, known as Beck triad, is characteristic of cardiac tamponade. Pulsus paradoxus, a drop in systolic blood pressure greater than 10 mmHg during inspiration, is due to decreased pericardial compliace and restricted ventricular filling. The chest radiograph shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette, suggesting significant pericardial effusion. A recent myocardial infarction can predispose to pericardial effusion and lead to cardiac tamponade. These elements collectively lead to reduced stroke volume and systemic hypotension.

Key learning point: Cardiac tamponade is characterized by dyspnea, pulsus paradoxus, hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and distended neck veins. X-ray typically shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette and clear lungs.

B) INCORRECT:

Tension pneumothorax presents with acute respiratory distress, unilateral absence of breath sounds, and radiographic evidence of lung collapse with mediastinal shift. The enlarged cardiac silhouette and absence of lung collapse or air accumulation on the radiograph are not consistent with this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Restrictive cardiomyopathy can present with elevated jugular venous pressure and peripheral edema, but pulsus paradoxus is more indicative of acute pericardial pathology. The enlarged cardiac silhouette without pulmonary edema and the recent myocardial infarction suggest a pericardial rather than myocardial issue.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute pericarditis typically presents with sharp, pleuritic chest pain that improves with sitting up and leaning forward, a pericardial friction rub, and diffuse ST-segment elevations on ECG. The presence of pulsus paradoxus and an enlarged cardiac silhouette suggests a hemodynamic compromise not explained by simple pericardial inflammation.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents with two days of chest discomfort, progressive shortness of breath, and mild confusion. Examination shows jugular venous distension with prominent neck veins, a difficult-to-palpate apical impulse, and muffled heart sounds. Lungs are clear on auscultation. There is a 15 mm Hg drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration. Blood tests are unremarkable (see reports).

Blood pressure
90/60 mm Hg


ECG: Non-specific low voltage QRS complexes
Chest X-ray: Enlarged cardiac outline with clear lung fields

Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Massive pulmonary embolism can cause chest discomfort and hypotension, but pulsus paradoxus and muffled heart sounds are more characteristic of pericardial pathology. The chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette, which is atypical for pulmonary embolism, where radiographic findings often differ.

B) CORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade manifests with jugular venous distension, muffled heart sounds, and a significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, known as pulsus paradoxus. These findings result from fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, compressing the heart and impairing diastolic filling. The low voltage QRS complexes on the electrocardiogram (ECG) occur due to the dampening effect of pericardial fluid on electrical signals. The chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette, consistent with a significant pericardial effusion. These clinical and imaging findings collectively indicate cardiac tamponade.

Key learning point: Cardiac tamponade is characterized by high JVP, pulsus paradoxus, distant heart sounds, low voltage ECG, and an increased cardiac silhouette on X-ray, indicating pericardial involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis typically develops over months to years and presents with chronic symptoms. The acute onset of symptoms and pulsus paradoxus are more indicative of cardiac tamponade. Additionally, the chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette, suggesting fluid accumulation rather than the dense pericardium seen in constrictive pericarditis.

D) INCORRECT:

Restrictive cardiomyopathy involves chronic diastolic dysfunction due to a stiff myocardium, leading to gradual symptom onset. The acute presentation with pulsus paradoxus and muffled heart sounds suggests an external constraint on cardiac filling, such as pericardial effusion, rather than restrictive cardiomyopathy.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man presents with sudden worsening of shortness of breath and severe fatigue. He has advanced malignancy. He appears anxious and tachycardic. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distension, muffled heart sounds, and a pulsus paradoxus of 14 mm Hg. He reports a dull chest pressure that has intensified over the past two days.


Heart rate
110/min


Blood pressure
90/58 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
22/min


Oxygen saturation
92% on room air


Which of the following diagnostic evaluations is most appropriate to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An electrocardiogram (ECG) may show low voltage QRS complexes and electrical alternans in pericardial effusion, but these findings are not sensitive or specific for cardiac tamponade. ECG does not quantify fluid accumulation or assess cardiac chamber compression, making it insufficient for confirming tamponade.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac MRI offers detailed cardiac assessment but is not suitable for acute hemodynamic compromise due to longer acquisition times and the need for patient stability. It is less practical in emergent settings compared to echocardiography for diagnosing cardiac tamponade.

C) INCORRECT:

A chest radiograph may show an enlarged cardiac silhouette in large pericardial effusions, but it lacks sensitivity and specificity, especially in acute cases. It does not provide dynamic information on hemodynamic compromise or effusion size, which are crucial for diagnosing cardiac tamponade.

D) CORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography is the preferred diagnostic tool for confirming cardiac tamponade, especially with clinical signs like jugular venous distension, muffled heart sounds, and pulsus paradoxus. It allows visualization of the pericardial space, assessing effusion size and dynamic cardiac features such as right atrial or ventricular diastolic collapse. In patients with advanced malignancy, malignant pericardial effusions are common, and echocardiography provides a rapid, non-invasive, and sensitive diagnosis, guiding management like pericardiocentesis.

Key learning point: In a patient with suspected cardiac tamponade, an echocardiogram is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis as it can visualize pericardial effusion and assess its impact on cardiac function.
Image Description:

Short video of a subxiphoid ultrasound examination of the heart (a marker indicates the probe position) showing a pericardial effusion

The right atrium (yellow overlay) is seen in the center of the image. The visceral pericardium (epicardium; red line) is clearly separated from the parietal and fibrous pericardium (green line) by a hypoechoic area (blue overlay), which corresponds to a pericardial effusion.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department with a stab wound to the left chest. He is diaphoretic and complains of severe chest pain. Examination shows jugular venous distention and distant heart sounds. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma reveals fluid in the pericardial sac. He remains hypotensive despite a rapid IV fluid bolus.


Heart rate
130/min


Blood pressure
80/50 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
28/min


What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endotracheal intubation is not the priority in this patient, as the primary issue is cardiac tamponade. The patient maintains adequate ventilation, and intubation could worsen hemodynamics by reducing venous return. The focus should be on pericardial decompression to address the tamponade.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with signs of cardiac tamponade, including hypotension, tachycardia, jugular venous distention, and muffled heart sounds, along with sonographic evidence of pericardial fluid. In cardiac tamponade, fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac restricts diastolic filling, reducing cardiac output and causing hemodynamic instability. Emergency pericardiocentesis is crucial to decompress the pericardial space, relieve pressure on the heart, and restore hemodynamic stability, especially in traumatic settings where fluid resuscitation fails to stabilize the patient.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected cardiac tamponade following chest trauma, pericardiocentesis is the immediate management to relieve pressure on the heart and stabilize the patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Inotropic support is used for myocardial pump failure, not for cardiac tamponade, where the issue is mechanical restriction of ventricular filling due to pericardial fluid. Inotropes do not relieve this compression and may worsen hemodynamics by increasing heart rate and reducing diastolic filling time.

D) INCORRECT:

Chest tube insertion is indicated for pleural space pathologies like hemothorax or tension pneumothorax. However, this patient exhibits signs of cardiac tamponade, not a pleural complication. The jugular venous distention, distant heart sounds, and pericardial fluid on sonography indicate a pericardial process, requiring pericardiocentesis rather than chest tube insertion.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after a high-speed vehicle collision. He has prominent jugular venous distension, bruising over the anterior chest, and muffled heart sounds. He does not complain of difficulty breathing, and lung auscultation reveals clear breath sounds bilaterally.


Heart rate
120/min


Blood pressure
88/50 mm Hg


Oxygen saturation
98% on room air


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary contusion results from blunt chest trauma, causing alveolar hemorrhage and edema, leading to respiratory distress and abnormal lung sounds. This patient has clear lung auscultation and normal oxygen saturation, which are inconsistent with pulmonary contusion. Jugular venous distension and muffled heart sounds indicate a cardiac process.

B) CORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade involves fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, compressing the heart and impairing diastolic filling. This results in reduced stroke volume and hypotension. Beck's triadhypotension, jugular venous distension, and muffled heart soundsis characteristic, as seen in this patient. Tachycardia compensates for decreased cardiac output. In trauma, pericardial bleeding from blunt chest injuries is common, making cardiac tamponade a likely diagnosis. Recognizing the pathophysiology of impaired ventricular filling and hemodynamic instability is essential for managing cardiac tamponade.

Key learning point: In the context of trauma, hypotension, distended neck veins, and ecchymosis on the chest wall suggest cardiac tamponade, especially when there is no evidence of respiratory distress or decreased breath sounds.

C) INCORRECT:

Massive hemothorax, often from blunt chest trauma, presents with hypotension and diminished breath sounds over the affected hemithorax due to blood accumulation. This patient has clear breath sounds bilaterally and normal oxygen saturation, which are not consistent with massive hemothorax. Jugular venous distension and muffled heart sounds suggest a cardiac issue.

D) INCORRECT:

Tension pneumothorax presents with hypotension, jugular venous distension, and respiratory distress due to intrapleural air. It typically causes unilateral absent breath sounds and tracheal deviation. This patient has clear breath sounds bilaterally and normal oxygen saturation, which are inconsistent with tension pneumothorax.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of sharp, retrosternal chest pain. The pain is rated 8 out of 10 in intensity, worsens with respiration, and improves when he sits upright and leans forward. He also reports nausea and myalgia. His temperature is 37.3째C, pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. On cardiac examination, you hear a high-pitched grating sound between S1 and S2. The remainder of the examination is normal. Serum studies show:


Urea, blood
5.7 mmol/L (2.18.0)


Glucose, fasting, blood
5.2 mmol/L (4.06.0)


Creatinine, blood
62 關mol/L (4993)


Troponin I, blood
230 ng/L ( 45)


An ECG shows diffuse ST elevations in all leads. This patient is at increased risk for which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary infarction is most commonly caused by pulmonary embolism (PE), which can also present with chest pain and nonspecific ST elevation. However, other common features of PE would be expected, including dyspnea, tachypnea, cough, hypotension, or signs of right ventricular pressure overload on ECG (e.g., right axis deviation). The absence of these symptoms in this case, as well as the presence of a friction rub on auscultation, make pulmonary embolism and therefore pulmonary infarction unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Pericarditis is a common cause of cardiac tamponade; it may occur in cases in which the pericardium becomes scarred and less elastic, while increased amounts of inflammatory fluids are secreted into the pericardial space. Cardiac tamponade can lead to hemodynamic compromise; therefore, treatment with pericardiocentesis is indicated.

Another complication of acute pericarditis is chronic, constrictive pericarditis, which may develop after several years.

Key learning point: Acute pericarditis can lead to cardiac tamponade due to accumulation of inflammatory fluid in the pericardial space, causing hemodynamic compromise.

C) INCORRECT:

Mediastinitis may occur as a result of esophageal disorders (e.g., Boerhaave syndrome). Patients with Boerhaave syndrome often present with a history of explosive vomiting and symptoms such as retrosternal pain and mediastinal emphysema (Mackler triad). The retrosternal pain seen in this patient makes Boerhaave syndrome an important differential diagnosis. However, in this case, the patient's history, auscultatory and ECG findings are suggestive of a different disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture is a life-threatening complication of acute myocardial infarction (MI) that leads to mitral regurgitation with subsequent hypotension and pulmonary edema. Although this patient presents with chest pain, symptoms of acute MI do not usually last for three consecutive days and present with ST elevations in anatomically contiguous leads on ECG.

E) INCORRECT:

A ventricular aneurysm is a late (> 3 weeks) complication of myocardial infarction (MI) that presents with persistent ST elevations and T wave inversions on ECG and can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and thromboembolisms. Although this patient presents with chest pain, symptoms of acute MI do not usually last for three consecutive days and present with more specific findings on ECG. Considering the timing and that MI is unlikely, ventricular aneurysm can be ruled out.
questions.hint: The patient's 3-day history of chest pain that increases with respiration and decreases while sitting up, in conjunction with a friction rub on cardiac auscultation, nausea, and myalgia, is suggestive of acute pericarditis. The ECG finding of ST elevations in all leads with a mild increase in troponin I further support the diagnosis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 46-year-old man in the emergency department with a 3-day history of dyspnea, dizziness, and chest and left shoulder pain. He underwent minimally invasive aortic valve replacement for a bicuspid aortic valve 2 weeks ago without complications. His pulse is 118/min and blood pressure is 85/60 mm Hg in both arms, with a 15 mm Hg decrease in systolic pressure on inspiration. He has jugular venous distention while sitting upright. Cardiac auscultation reveals distant first and second heart sounds, with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. A postoperative chest radiograph from 2 weeks ago is compared to a current radiograph (figure). Which one of the following diagnostic steps should be taken next?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography and aortography are appropriate for diagnosing aortic dissection, but the clinical presentation is more consistent with pericardial tamponade.

B) CORRECT:

Subacute cardiac tamponade, the most likely explanation for the patient's findings, can occur after cardiac surgery due to inflammation of the pericardium. Transthoracic echocardiography can confirm the diagnosis rapidly and guide needle pericardiocentesis, if indicated; transesophageal echocardiography is not necessary for this purpose.

Key learning point: Two weeks after undergoing aortic valve repair, a patient presents with shortness of breath, hypotension with an additional fall in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, jugular venous distention, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest radiograph. The most appropriate diagnostic test is transthoracic echocardiography.

C) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography and aortography are appropriate for diagnosing aortic dissection, but the clinical presentation is more consistent with pericardial tamponade.

D) INCORRECT:

Although postoperative pulmonary embolism should be considered in a patient who is hypotensive, tachycardic, and tachypneic, the radiograph findings suggest an enlarged cardiac silhouette consistent with a pericardial effusion, which would not be expected with a pulmonary embolism.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography is not the best next step in this patient. It is an invasive procedure, and myocardial ischemia is not the most likely diagnosis with this clinical presentation.
questions.hint: Muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and jugular venous distention (also known as Beck's triad) indicate that this patient likely has cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: You are seeing a 24-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after sustaining a stab wound to the left chest. On arrival, he has rapid, shallow breathing and appears anxious. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min and shallow, and his palpable systolic blood pressure is 80 mm Hg. There is a 2.5-cm stab wound at the 4th intercostal space in the left midclavicular line. Cardiovascular examination reveals muffled heart sounds and jugular venous distention. Breath sounds are normal. Further evaluation is most likely to show which one of the following findings?

choices.text: Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing.
Herniation of the stomach into the chest.
A drop in systolic blood pressure of 14 mm Hg during inspiration.
Tracheal deviation toward the right side.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing suggests flail chest, which is usually caused by severe blunt thoracic trauma rather than penetrating chest trauma. Although this patient has shallow breathing, which may be a feature of flail chest, the condition is not associated with muffled heart sounds or jugular venous distention, and it is unlikely that a single stab wound would cause several rib fractures.

B) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous emphysema or crepitus suggests either bronchial rupture, esophageal rupture, or pneumothorax, which also may be caused by penetrating trauma. None of these conditions cause muffled heart sounds.

C) INCORRECT:

Herniation of the stomach into the chest indicates diaphragmatic injury. This condition may also result after a penetrating chest trauma. Although shallow breathing is a feature consistent with diaphragmatic injury, this patient is lacking other key findings of this condition, such as chest or abdominal pain, reduced breath sounds, and bowel sounds in the chest on auscultation. In addition, muffled heart sounds would not be expected in this condition.

D) CORRECT:

In cardiac tamponade, outward expansion of the ventricles is limited because of fluid in the pericardial space. During inspiration, increased venous return leads to increased right ventricular volume. As outward expansion is limited, the right ventricle expands via the interventricular septum, which bulges into the left ventricle. This effect leads to further reduction in left ventricular filling during inspiration, resulting in decreased stroke volume and a subsequent drop in blood pressure. A drop in systolic blood pressure > 10 mm Hg during inspiration is known as pulsus paradoxus, a sign characteristically seen in moderate and severe cardiac tamponade but also in some cases of severe asthma, tension pneumothorax, and constrictive pericarditis.

Key learning point: Cardiac tamponade is characterized by pulsus paradoxus, a drop in systolic blood pressure greater than 10 mm Hg during inspiration due to impaired ventricular filling.

E) INCORRECT:

Tracheal deviation toward the contralateral side of a lesion can occur with a tension pneumothorax or a massive hemothorax. Although both of these conditions can be caused by penetrating chest trauma and result in tachycardia, hypotension, and jugular venous distention, this patient does not have reduced breath sounds, which is a characteristic auscultatory finding in both of these conditions.
questions.hint: Muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and jugular venous distention (also known as Beck triad) following penetrating chest trauma are consistent with cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of lung cancer presents to the emergency department with fatigue and dyspnea. He is alert and oriented. Vital signs are BP, 88/52; P, 124; R, 26; oxygen saturation, 92% on room air. Point-of-care ultrasound examination is shown. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although tension pneumothorax can occur in patients with lung cancer who have dyspnea and hemodynamic instability, it does not cause a hypoechoic collection around the heart, which is seen on this patient's ultrasound.

B) INCORRECT:

Chest tube placement is appropriate for treating pneumothorax or hemothorax, which can occur in patients with lung cancer who have dyspnea and hemodynamic instability. Pneumothorax and hemothorax do not, however, result in a hypoechoic collection around the heart, which is seen on this patient's ultrasound. Drainage of the pleural space does not address the condition most likely causing this patient's clinical presentation.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's ultrasound finding of a hypoechoic collection around the heart is diagnostic for a pericardial effusion with tamponade, emergency thoracotomy is not the first-line treatment. Emergency thoracotomy is usually reserved for patients in cardiac arrest or with traumatic cardiac tamponade.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The ultrasound finding of an anechoic rim around the heart confirms pericardial effusion, most likely of malignant origin. In hemodynamically unstable patients with cardiac tamponade, immediate pericardiocentesis is the preferred treatment to decompress the pericardial space.

E) INCORRECT:

The ultrasound finding of an anechoic rim around the heart confirms pericardial effusion causing cardiac tamponade in this hemodynamically unstable patient. Fluid resuscitation should only be attempted with caution in patients with obstructive shock because it can paradoxically worsen cardiac tamponade by increasing venous return and pericardial pressure. Treating the underlying cause of obstructive shock is the safest option.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer presents with progressive dyspnea over 3 days. Vital signs are BP, 82/48; P, 122; R, 26. Physical examination shows elevated jugular venous pressure, distant heart sounds, and pulsus paradoxus of 22 mm Hg. Point-of-care ultrasound shows a large pericardial effusion with right ventricular collapse during diastole. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Formal echocardiography provides additional information but should not delay immediate intervention in a hemodynamically unstable patient with clear evidence of tamponade on point-of-care ultrasound.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has cardiac tamponade, as evidenced by hemodynamic instability, elevated jugular venous pressure, distant heart sounds, significant pulsus paradoxus (> 1012 mm Hg), and echocardiographic findings of right ventricular collapse. Immediate pericardiocentesis with ultrasound guidance is the treatment of choice for unstable patients with cardiac tamponade. This procedure is life-saving and should not be delayed.

C) INCORRECT:

While vasopressors may temporarily improve blood pressure, they do not address the underlying mechanical obstruction to ventricular filling. Vasopressors also increase myocardial oxygen demand without improving cardiac output.

D) INCORRECT:

Diuretics are contraindicated in cardiac tamponade because they reduce preload, which worsens the already compromised ventricular filling. Patients with tamponade are preload-dependent, and reducing intravascular volume can lead to cardiovascular collapse.

E) INCORRECT:

While cardiothoracic surgery consultation is important for ongoing management, obtaining a consultation should not delay definitive treatment in this hemodynamically unstable patient. Surgery is typically reserved for unsuccessful pericardiocentesis or specific conditions such as aortic dissection.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of lung cancer presents with progressive dyspnea and orthopnea over 5 days. Vital signs are BP, 85/50; P, 115; R, 24. Physical examination shows distended neck veins and distant heart sounds. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with consecutive QRS complexes alternating in amplitude. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While echocardiography is the gold standard for diagnosing pericardial effusion, it should not delay treatment in an unstable patient with clear clinical signs of tamponade. This patient has Beck triad components and electrical alternans, which provide sufficient clinical evidence of tamponade.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization is not indicated in the acute management of cardiac tamponade. While cardiac catheterization might show equalization of diastolic pressures in all chambers, this invasive procedure delays necessary treatment and is not appropriate for an unstable patient.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with clinical signs of cardiac tamponade, including hypotension, tachycardia, distended neck veins, and electrical alternans on ECG. The ECG finding of alternating QRS amplitude results from the swinging motion of the heart within pericardial fluid. In hemodynamically unstable patients with tamponade, immediate pericardiocentesis should not be delayed for diagnostic confirmation.

D) INCORRECT:

Chest CT provides detailed anatomic information but is inappropriate for an unstable patient requiring immediate intervention. This patient's clinical presentation suggests tamponade, and delaying treatment may result in cardiovascular collapse.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous fluid administration is contraindicated in cardiac tamponade because it can worsen venous congestion without improving cardiac output. This patient has mechanical compression of the heart, not volume depletion, and drainage is indicated rather than fluid resuscitation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with progressive dyspnea over 3 days. Vital signs are BP, 85/60; P, 118; R, 24. Physical examination shows distant heart sounds and elevated jugular venous pressure. Point-of-care ultrasound demonstrates a 12-mm anechoic space surrounding the heart. Which echocardiographic finding would most strongly support the need for immediate pericardiocentesis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pericardial thickening suggests chronic pericardial disease rather than acute tamponade physiology. While thickening may be present in some patients with acute tamponade, it does not indicate hemodynamic compromise requiring immediate pericardiocentesis.

B) CORRECT:

Correct Left atrial collapse during diastole is a late, highly specific finding (98% specificity) for cardiac tamponade that indicates severe hemodynamic compromise requiring immediate intervention. This finding occurs after right atrial and right ventricular collapse in the progression of tamponade.

C) INCORRECT:

Swinging motion of the heart occurs in tamponade due to fluid in the pericardial space but is not as specific as chamber collapse findings. A swinging motion can be seen in large effusions without necessarily indicating the need for immediate drainage.

D) INCORRECT:

Inferior vena cava plethora is a supportive finding in tamponade but is not specific to this condition. Inferior vena cava plethora can occur with other causes of right heart failure and does not indicate the same urgency as another finding.

E) INCORRECT:

Electrical alternans is an ECG finding, not an echocardiographic finding. While electrical alternans can occur in tamponade due to the swinging motion of the heart, this finding is not visualized on ultrasound and is less specific than another finding.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with 3 weeks of progressive dyspnea. She had similar symptoms that resolved with treatment 4 months ago and was treated for breast cancer 2 years ago. Vital signs are BP, 105/65; P, 110. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension and distant heart sounds. Echocardiography shows a large pericardial effusion with right ventricular diastolic collapse. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Consult cardiothoracic surgery for pericardial window

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose corticosteroids are used for inflammatory pericarditis. This patient's cancer history, subacute timeline, and recurrent symptoms suggest malignant rather than inflammatory etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

Colchicine is used for acute idiopathic or viral pericarditis and recurrent pericarditis. This patient's cancer history and clinical presentation suggest malignant rather than idiopathic etiology.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation suggests malignant pericardial effusion based on subacute progression over 3 weeks, history of breast cancer, and previous episode of dyspnea 4 months ago. Pericardial window surgery is the preferred definitive treatment for malignant effusions because it provides drainage while preventing reaccumulation, which is common with malignant etiology.

D) INCORRECT:

Diuretics are contraindicated in cardiac tamponade because they reduce preload, which can worsen hemodynamic compromise. This patient shows signs of early tamponade with right ventricular diastolic collapse and requires definitive intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

While pericardiocentesis provides immediate relief, this patients subacute course, cancer history, and recurrent symptoms suggest malignant effusion. Pericardiocentesis alone, without definitive treatment, often leads to rapid reaccumulation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with progressive dyspnea and chest discomfort that began 6 hours ago. She underwent cardiac catheterization with stent placement 2 days ago. Vital signs are BP, 88/55; P, 122; R, 28. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension and distant heart sounds. Point-of-care ultrasound shows a large pericardial effusion with right atrial collapse during systole and right ventricular collapse during early diastole. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: Formal transthoracic echocardiography for detailed assessment
Immediate cardiothoracic surgery consultation for pericardial window
Chest CT angiography to evaluate for aortic dissection
Intravenous fluid bolus followed by dobutamine infusion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Formal echocardiography should not delay treatment in unstable patients with tamponade. This patient's point-of-care ultrasound findings already show tamponade physiology, which requires immediate intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

While surgical consultation is appropriate, immediate pericardiocentesis should not be delayed in unstable patients unless specific contraindications are present, such as suspected ventricular rupture or aortic dissection with hemopericardium.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with clinical signs of cardiac tamponade (hypotension, tachycardia, elevated jugular venous pressure, distant heart sounds) and echocardiographic findings consistent with tamponade physiology (chamber collapse). In unstable patients with tamponade, immediate pericardiocentesis under ultrasound guidance is the definitive treatment and should not be delayed.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation and recent cardiac intervention are more consistent with tamponade than with aortic dissection. CT angiography causes an unnecessary delay in hemodynamically unstable patients with clear evidence of cardiac tamponade.

E) INCORRECT:

While hemodynamic support may be considered in patients with tamponade, excessive fluid administration may increase pericardial pressure and worsen tamponade physiology.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer presents with worsening dyspnea and fatigue. She appears diaphoretic. Vital signs are BP, 78/45; P, 135. There is elevated jugular venous pressure. Bedside echocardiography shows a large pericardial effusion with diastolic collapse of the right ventricle and respiratory variation in mitral inflow velocity > 25%. The patient has poor peripheral IV access from prior chemotherapy. Cardiology is arranging urgent pericardiocentesis. What is the most appropriate initial management priority?

choices.text: Administer 500 mL normal saline bolus and reassess hemodynamics
Withhold routine fluid administration and consider dobutamine for inotropic support
Initiate continuous normal saline infusion at 125 mL/hr
Initiate 250 mL fluid challenge while monitoring central venous pressure
Administer 1 liter normal saline to optimize preload before starting vasopressors

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluid boluses can worsen tamponade physiology by increasing pericardial pressure and further compromising ventricular filling. Because the rigid pericardium cannot accommodate additional volume, aggressive fluid resuscitation is counterproductive.

B) CORRECT:

Correct In cardiac tamponade, the primary problem is impaired ventricular filling due to external compression, not hypovolemia. Avoiding unnecessary fluid prevents worsening of tamponade physiology, and inotropic support can help optimize cardiac output from the limited preload available.

C) INCORRECT:

Even modest fluid administration can exacerbate the hemodynamic compromise by increasing intrapericardial pressure in the noncompliant pericardial space.

D) INCORRECT:

Small-volume fluid challenges are appropriate when hypotension is due to reduced preload. In cardiac tamponade, the limiting factor is pericardial constraint, and even small fluid boluses can worsen hemodynamics. Additionally, central venous pressure monitoring does not change acute management.

E) INCORRECT:

Large-volume fluid administration significantly worsens cardiac tamponade by increasing pericardial pressure.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a 6-hour history of progressive dyspnea and chest discomfort. She underwent radiation therapy for breast cancer 18 months ago and has chronic systolic heart failure. Vital signs are BP, 88/65; P, 115; R, 24; oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension, muffled heart sounds, and clear lung fields. Point-of-care ultrasound demonstrates a circumferential pericardial effusion with right ventricular diastolic collapse. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to ICU for monitoring and serial echocardiography
Begin anticoagulation for presumed pulmonary embolism

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has a history of heart failure, her presentation is consistent with cardiac tamponade. Diuresis reduces preload and worsens hemodynamic compromise in cardiac tamponade.

B) INCORRECT:

Monitoring alone is insufficient in unstable tamponade.

C) INCORRECT:

Normal lung examination and ultrasound findings indicate tamponade, not pulmonary embolism. Anticoagulation should be avoided in acute tamponade until the etiology is known and bleeding has been excluded, as it could result in more intrapericardial bleeding and worsen tamponade.

D) CORRECT:

Correct This patient's presentation is consistent with cardiac tamponade, which is life-threatening and requires immediate drainage of the pericardial space. Hemodynamic compromise occurs because rapid fluid accumulation prevents adequate ventricular filling, leading to obstructive shock. Emergency pericardiocentesis relieves the pressure and restores cardiac output.

E) INCORRECT:

Steroids may treat pericarditis in select patients but have no role in acute tamponade management.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with severe dyspnea and lightheadedness. She has a history of metastatic lung cancer. She appears anxious and tachypneic. Her temperature is 37.1째C (98.8째F), heart rate is 128/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 85/60 mm Hg. On examination, her jugular veins are distended to the angle of the jaw. Heart sounds are distant, and lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia and low-voltage QRS complexes. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial intervention?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intubation is considered for impending respiratory failure. However, this patient's dyspnea is due to low cardiac output from tamponade, not a primary pulmonary issue. Importantly, the positive pressure ventilation initiated after intubation decreases venous return (preload). In a patient with tamponade who is already critically preload-dependent, this can precipitate cardiovascular collapse.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous fluids are often used to manage hypotension. In cardiac tamponade, fluids can transiently increase preload and right-sided filling pressures, which may temporarily improve cardiac output. However, this is only a temporizing measure that does not address the underlying mechanical compression of the heart. Delaying the definitive procedure for aggressive fluid resuscitation is not the most appropriate initial step.

C) CORRECT:

The definitive and most appropriate initial intervention for hemodynamically unstable patients with cardiac tamponade is urgent pericardiocentesis to drain the fluid, relieve the pressure on the heart, and restore normal cardiac filling and function. Treatmentshould not be delayedfor diagnostic confirmation. Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition of obstructive shock in which pericardial fluid compresses the heart, impairing diastolic filling and reducing cardiac output. The cause in this patient is most likelymalignant pericardial effusionfrommetastatic lung cancer. The ECG findings of low-voltage QRS complexes further support this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is a diuretic used to treat volume overload, which can cause jugular venous distention. However, this patient's clear lungs make volume overload unlikely. In cardiac tamponade, cardiac output is highly dependent on preload. Administering a diuretic would decrease preload, further impairing ventricular filling and worsening the hypotension and obstructive shock.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of hypotension, jugular venous distention, and distant heart sounds constitutes Beck triad, which suggests a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue. Her symptoms are exacerbated by exertion and lying flat. She has a history of stage II estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer diagnosed 5 years ago, for which she completed treatment with lumpectomy, radiation, and tamoxifen. Her temperature is 37.1째C (98.8째F), blood pressure is 98/76 mm Hg, pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 22/min. On inspiration, her systolic blood pressure drops to 85 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention and distant heart sounds. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While this patient's history of chest radiation is a risk factor for pericardial disease, constrictive pericarditis is less likely. Constriction involves a thickened, fibrotic pericardium that restricts diastolic filling, but it typically develops years to decades after radiation. The chest x-ray in constrictive pericarditis usually shows a normal-sized heart, sometimes with pericardial calcifications, not the enlarged, globular silhouette seen in this patient, which indicates a large fluid collection.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with cardiac tamponade, a life-threatening condition caused by the accumulation of pericardial fluid that compresses the heart and impairs diastolic filling. Key findings include Beck triad (hypotension, jugular venous distention, and distant heart sounds) and pulsus paradoxus (an inspiratory drop in systolic blood pressure > 10 mm Hg). The globular cardiac silhouette on chest x-ray further supports a large pericardial effusion. Given her history of breast cancer, a malignant pericardial effusion due to metastatic disease is the most likely underlying cause. Lung cancer, breast cancer, and lymphoma are the most common malignancies that cause pericardial metastases. The subacute onset over weeks is typical for a gradually accumulating malignant effusion.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute decompensated heart failure can manifest with dyspnea, orthopnea, tachycardia, and jugular venous distention. However, this diagnosis does not typically cause distant heart sounds or a significant pulsus paradoxus. Furthermore, the classic globular or "water bottle" shape of the cardiac silhouette on a chest x-ray is highly specific for a large pericardial effusion, not intrinsic myocardial failure.

D) INCORRECT:

A large pulmonary embolism can cause dyspnea, tachycardia, hypotension, and jugular venous distention due to acute right heart strain. This patient's history of malignancy is also a risk factor. However, a pulmonary embolism would not explain the distant heart sounds, the significant pulsus paradoxus, or the globular cardiac silhouette on the chest x-ray, all of which are hallmarks of a large pericardial effusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Viral pericarditis is a common cause of pericardial effusion, but it typically has a more acute onset with pleuritic chest pain, fever, and often a preceding viral prodrome. This patient's subacute onset over 3 weeks without fever or chest pain makes a viral cause less probable.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of hypotension, jugular venous distention, and distant heart sounds (Beck triad), along with a significant pulsus paradoxus, is classic for cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with progressive dyspnea and lightheadedness. She has a history of metastatic lung cancer. Her blood pressure is 88/60 mm Hg, pulse is 125/min, and respirations are 24/min. Physical examination shows distended neck veins and distant heart sounds. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on physical examination?

choices.text: Unequal blood pressure in the upper extremities
An exaggerated decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration
A holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla
A triphasic friction rub at the left sternal border

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A significant difference in systolic blood pressure between the arms is a classic finding in aortic dissection, which can cause hypotension and dyspnea. Although a proximal dissection can rupture into the pericardium and cause tamponade, the unequal blood pressure is a sign of the dissection itself, not the resulting tamponade physiology. The other findings are more specific to tamponade.

B) INCORRECT:

Bilateral crackles suggest pulmonary edema, which is typically caused by left-sided heart failure or volume overload. This patient's lungs are explicitly described as clear to auscultation, which argues against cardiogenic shock from primary left ventricular failure and suggests an obstructive cause of her symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

An exaggerated decrease in systolic blood pressure during inspiration describes pulsus paradoxus, a typical feature of cardiac tamponade. During inspiration, increased venous return to the right ventricle causes the interventricular septum to bow into the left ventricle. In tamponade, this septal shift is exaggerated due to the fixed pericardial volume, severely compromising left ventricular filling and stroke volume. This leads to a drop in systolic blood pressure of more than 10 mm Hg during inspiration. An electrocardiogram would likely show low-voltage QRS complexes and electrical alternans.

D) INCORRECT:

A holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla is characteristic of mitral regurgitation. Although acute severe mitral regurgitation can cause hypotension and dyspnea, it typically leads to cardiogenic shock with pulmonary edema (crackles), not the distended neck veins and distant heart sounds that occur with impaired cardiac filling from an external pressure source.

E) INCORRECT:

A pericardial friction rub is a classic sign of acute pericarditis, which can be a precursor to pericardial effusion and tamponade. However, as a significant effusion accumulates and separates the visceral and parietal layers of the pericardium, the friction rub often diminishes or disappears entirely. Therefore, it is less likely to be present in a patient with established tamponade physiology.
questions.hint: This patient's hypotension, distended neck veins, and distant heart sounds form a classic triad (Beck triad) suggestive of cardiac tamponade.
